headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Williams Companies Fourth Quarter 2010 Earnings Release Conference Call. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I'd like to turn the conference over to Mr. Travis Campbell, Head of Investor Relations. P
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Williams Companies Fourth Quarter 2010 Earnings Release Conference Call. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I'd like to turn the conference over to Mr. Travis Campbell, Head of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you and good morning, everybody. Welcome to our fourth quarter 2010 earnings call. As always, thank you for the interest in our company. Initially, I would mention that on our website, www.williams.com, you should be able to find a number of thing
componenttext:
Thank you and good morning, everybody. Welcome to our fourth quarter 2010 earnings call. As always, thank you for the interest in our company. 
Initially, I would mention that on our website, www.williams.com, you should be able to find a number of things. First, the slides that we will be talking from this morning. Second, the data book that contains the usual information we make available each quarter. And finally, three press releases. First, separation release that we issued last evening. Second, the reported fourth quarter results. And third, our year-end oil and gas reserves. Now the last two were issued this morning.
In a minute, Alan Armstrong, our President and CEO, will review the few slides we have this morning. Be aware though that as always, all of our business units heads are here and are available to respond to questions after Alan's remarks. 
Here with me are Ralph Hill, who heads the E&P company; Rory Miller, who recently took over the reins of the midstream company; and Phil Wright, who heads our Gas Pipelines.
Also, you certainly saw the notice that Phil will be taking another role in the company later this month and Randy Bernard is going to lead the Gas Pipelines and he's with us as well. Also, Don Chappel, the CFO is here as well.
As most of you are aware, yesterday, we announced our plan to separate our E&P business to a partial IPO and a subsequent spinoff of our remaining ownership interest. Alan will make brief remarks about this plan during his comments. But because of security law restrictions, we will not be commenting further or taking any questions on the E&P separation during this call. I will direct your attention to the press release that went out yesterday.
At the beginning of the slide deck are the forward-looking statements on Slide Number 2 and Number 3. And the disclaimer on oil and gas reserves on Slide Number 4. Those are important and integral to the remarks, so please review those. 
Also included are various non-GAAP numbers that have been reconciled back to Generally Accepted Accounting Principles. Those schedules are available in all presentations.
With that, I'll turn it over to Alan.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. Good morning, and I'll start here on Slide 5.I'm certainly pleased to join us for our call this morning and to hear about our strong finish to 2010 and an exciting future for Williams shareholders.Our management and board have worked diligently
componenttext:
Great. Good morning, and I'll start here on Slide 5.
I'm certainly pleased to join us for our call this morning and to hear about our strong finish to 2010 and an exciting future for Williams shareholders.
Our management and board have worked diligently over the last couple of months analyzing the best path to unlock shareholder value while maintaining growth platforms for the future.
As Travis mentioned, we will not be able to provide details of the transactions or forward-looking perspectives of the new E&P company. Despite this restriction, we have plenty of exciting information to share with you about WMB's 2010 performance and the growth drivers for the future.
I'm also pleased to inform you that we exceeded our earlier guidance range for earnings per share, and we are raising guidance for 2011 and 2012.
And with that, I'll move on to Slide 6. As we announced yesterday, our board has given us a green light to pursue the creation of a separate E&P company, starting with a partial IPO in the third quarter of 2011, and then a planned spinoff for the remaining interest to our shareholders in 2012.
WMB would use the IPO proceeds to pay down corporate debt, and we would expect to maintain investment grade credit ratings at the WMB and WPZ. I would refer you to the press releases from the three credit rating agencies that rate our debt that came out shortly after our announcement yesterday if you'd like to know their perspectives in more detail.
This new structure enables WMB to initiate a high dividend strategy. We are announcing a 60% increase, starting with quarterly payout in June of 2011, going from $0.0125 to $0.20 per quarter, and we are targeting an additional 10% to 15% increase in June of 2012.
Both of these actions are a direct response to hearing from our shareholders and gathering thoughts over the last, actually, several years in terms of thinking about how we can increase shareholder value. So we're pleased to be reporting this to you this morning.
WMB and WPZ will be focused on meeting robust demand for new infrastructure that helps our customers and our nation take advantage of North America's abundant natural resources. As you will see, we have lot of new infrastructure being built and plan to do just that.
Moving on to Slide 7. Our full year financial results were boosted by a very strong fourth quarter. Our adjusted net income for the fourth quarter was up 60% over the same quarter in 2009. This drove our adjusted EPS from continuing operations for 2010 to a $1.28 per share, and that is 36% higher than our 2009 level of $0.94.
As you know, our full year GAAP was heavily impacted by non-cash impairment charges in the third quarter, and we had a significant cost related to the WPZ and WMZ merger and the related debt restructurings required for that transaction.
For the year, we are ending up at a GAAP loss of $1.1 billion. And on an adjusted basis, net income was $760 million, which was up 38% over the same number for 2009.
I won't spend much time here on the reserves since we provide some great graphics here on the next couple of slides that I'll explain the reserves with. 
And moving into Slide 8. You can see here starting with the left-hand side, you can see our year-end 2009 reserves, and you can see the various adjustments to get us to our 2010 U.S. reserves, then we add in the international reserves from Apco. And then finally, you see the adjusted total reserves as we look at what it would mean if we looked at a total of seven years of reserves to get to.
So our net proved reserves held strong with 107% reserve replacement ratio, but did not move up radically, predominantly, due to the new SEC five-year limit rule under which we reclassified about 250 Bcf of proved reserves to probable in the Piceance due to reducing the pace of drilling in a lower-price environment and no longer being able to get to all previously amounts within the five years.
This in no way means we can't or don't expect to get to those reserves, just reclassification under the SEC rules.
If you look at our net additions and revisions, we added 528 Bcf through our drilling program in which we spent $984 million in the E&P development capital. So this equates to, in 2010, a finding cost of $1.86.
We ended the year at 4.3 Tcf of domestic proved. And adding additional international you can see raises at to 4.5 Tcf. We've also identified an additional 353 Bcf of reserves that could be classified as proved, if we were allowed to add two more years of development. In other words, seven years of development instead of being limited to five.
Under this alternative view of how we would've looked at things before the SEC five-year rule was imposed, our adjusted proved reserves would have grown to more than 4.8 Tcf.
Moving on to Slide 9. You can see a big move here on our 3P reserves. And moving from about 14.8 Tcf to just under 16 Tcf, and this was driven predominantly by our undeveloped leasehold, acquisitions in both the Marcellus Shale and the Bakken Oil Play. 
And our drilling programs are now well-diversified among some of the most economically attractive plays in the country, including the Marcellus Shale, the Bakken Oil and the Piceance tight sands done the Williams' way.
Moving on to 10. Here, as mentioned earlier, we had a 60% increase in adjusted net income for the quarter. In addition, our teams worked tirelessly to close stunning amount of transactions in the quarter as listed here. 
We also saw our NGL production rebound tremendously in the fourth quarter after a difficult third quarter. And this represented a record for our WPZ operations. This was driven by the startup of our new Echo Springs plant, but was partially offset by the sell of our Cameron Meadows plant in the fourth quarter of 2009.
As you can see, the two large acquisitions done by WPZ are large fee-based deals, with little or no direct commodity exposure. And as we've commented a lot in the past, we continue to try to take advantage when we see good fee-based opportunities to continue to steady the incomes of our WPZ investments.
The scale that we brought to WPZ through our restructuring in the first quarter of 2010 enabled us to perform these large transactions without straining our balance sheet. So we really were able to really prove the value of our WPZ transaction in a very large way in the fourth quarter of '10.
And speaking of that, moving on here to Slide 11, the Bakken acquisition is a great example of the fruits that our WPZ restructuring brought forth. The drop-down of the Piceance gathering system that WPZ enabled this exciting $925 million acquisition. 
Nothing new on the slide, but we have now updated guidance to include it. And other than the weather this time of the year in North Dakota, we are very pleased about our large entry in the Bakken and Three Forks oil play in North Dakota. 
We closed the transaction on December 21 and we have three rigs running there. And certainly, in the process of getting our teams assembled and getting a lot of the great experience that we have around the organization zeroed in on the opportunities in the Bakken.
Moving on to Slide 12. A lot of exciting things going on here in the Marcellus, and almost too much to mention. But I'll take a stab at it here. Our Transco [Transcontinental] Gas Pipeline group announced recently that it executed agreements with three shippers that fully subscribed in Northeast Supply Link project on a long-term basis. These shippers included Hess, Anadarko and Williams Gas Marketing.
The Northeast Supply Link project is a proposed expansion of the Transco Pipeline System that will provide about 250,000 dekatherms per day of incremental firm transportation capacity from Marcellus Shale supplies into Station 210 Polling Point in New Jersey and even all the way into existing New York City delivery points.
Williams expects to submit its first application by the end of the year, and subject to perk [perquisites] approval, the budget will be placed in the service in November 2013. This is really exciting project for us because it shows the way our Midstream business can work with the Gas Pipeline business. The largest customer commitment for this Transco project is coming from Midstreams's 33-mile Springville lateral interconnect, that is to be completed now in July of 2011.
The midstream efforts in both Northeast Pennsylvania and Southwest Pennsylvania are expected to enable the gathering of 2 Bcf per day in 2013 and 2.75 Bcf per day in 2015. So we're very excited to see the way things are growing there in both the midstream area, the gas pipe area and as well, the E&P area. 
Notes on the E&P, we continue to see improving well results. Our Clearfield County, Alder Run wells are on line at 2 million to 4 million cubic feet per day each. And we are in the process of completing a 3D seismic acquisition for Susquehanna and Westmoreland Counties and the center in Clearfield County shoot will begin very quickly. Progress towards building out the permit inventory, adding staff and vendors and contractors continue there as well.
Moving on to Slide 13. Here we show our commodity price assumptions that support our earnings guidance. The big shift was moving NYMEX natural gas midpoint down to $4.25 from $5 for 2011, and raising the midpoint for our WTI crude oil up to $87.50 from $80.
The gas is in line with the current forward strip and the crude oil is slightly conservative to the strip, as you all are probably aware. In 2012, our NYMEX gas was lowered to $5 from $5.40. And WTI oil is going up from $82 to $89 in 2012. So those are just the changes that we've made from the previous guidance. And as well, the WTI there remains conservative to the strip.
Of course, the NGL margin moves up with these new assumptions despite embedding a much more conservative NGL to crude relationship than we saw in 2010. The actual NGL to crude relationship came in at 55% in 2010. And our midpoint here for 2011 is 53%, and you can see rising up to 54% for 2012.
Our belief, and if you follow the logic here, our belief is that the NGL to crude relationships move inversely to crude to gas ratio. So as we're seeing a higher crude to gas ratio in 2011, we're suggesting that we should see a slip in the NGL to crude ratio. Despite that, we continue to show very strong margins here in 2011.
Moving onto Slide 14. That commodity assumptions then reflect a nice lift in our guidance as well along with the Bakken acquisition. Our earnings per share reflects some tightening of the ranges in '11 and '12. And our midpoint is being raised from $1.25 to $1.40 for 2011. And to $1.75 from $1.50 in 2012.
The segment profit also has tightened. We're also tightening the range for 2011 and a slight increase in the range in 2012. The segment profit as you'd see has moved up by a little over 7% in 2011 and about 10% for 2012.
The drivers of course for these earnings raising in segment profit going up are acquisitions that were made in the fourth quarter and higher NGL margins that are being partially offset by lower natural gas prices.
And you also would note, if you dig into the detail here, you'll note that our 2011 and 2012 CapEx are raising. Part of that is carryover from 2010 to '11, as well as increased growth opportunities in the WPZ Laurel Mountain and the Piceance growth as well. So quite a bit of new capital coming there that will continue to fuel our growth.
Moving on to Slide 15. Impressive adjusted segment profit growth here from '10 to '12 of 35%. This segment profit growth is made up of 31% in the Other category and 79% in E&P and a 26% increase in WPZ. In fact, our Other category is getting so big, it's just about to earn its stripes and get a real name. So you'll see notes of that in our 10-K release as well. But really, very nice segment profit growth across the board for all three units here.
Moving on to Slide 16. Talking about we have here $4 billion in growth capital in '11 and '12 to spend. So that's just the growth side CapEx. And we have many more projects as you'll see here in the next few slides beyond the guidance period. And many speculative projects that we have not built in the guidance yet. Of course, our track record demonstrates our ability to grow even faster than our guidance, and we continue our able to add on projects to the back-end of our CapEx for guidance.
Moving on to Slide 17. Much of the continued spending in guidance is growing our fee-based business here. As you can see, within Midstream, in the Marcellus, and we continue to see a big opportunity, albeit more speculative, in the deepwater services as well. As you can see there on the left, you see where the Gulf Coast G&P gets larger as a percentage of the overall mix.
So a lot of great opportunity out there, tremendous demand for midstream infrastructure, particularly in the upstream sector, and we're excited about beginning to help service the pet chem side as well as a lot of changes are coming forward in the pet chem side that are going to demand some infrastructure changes as well, and we're well-positioned to help up with that.
Moving on to Slide 18. Our opportunities in Canada and domestic olefins continue to impress. A relative low cost natural gas resources are creating great opportunities for the North American pet chem space. And we are very excited to be a part of it. 
We are able to utilize our knowledge and access to the light and NGLs, both here in the U.S. and Canada. And very well-positioned because we have $500 million of international cash at the end of the year that is sitting available to invest. So we're not going to have to raise any financing to fuel some very substantial growth in Canada. And you can see there the projects listed on here, the Boreal NGL pipeline, which is the right in the midst of construction, reminds you that construction pipelines in Canada, in that part of the country, really does require winter construction on the Northern and because the ground is to be frozen, and we are right in the midst of construction there.
The ethane recovery project, we continue to be excited about that and that will add to our current services up there that will add our ability to extract ethane and ethylene from those resources up there. And then, of course, we remain very confident in our ability to again the other upgrade processing benefit, and we've conclude here in the guidance as well.
Move on to the gas pipelines there. You can see here, really, the key message here is that there's about $1.3 billion of inventory for growth project, but the real key message is that most of this $1.3 billion majority comes on either in late 2012 or even beyond the guidance period, most of it even beyond the guidance period. So despite nice increase that we've got in our guidance, we've got a very nice group of projects here that will fuel our growth beyond the guidance period.
Moving on here to Slide 20 and in closing here. In the current, we exceeded our EPS guidance. We plan to take dramatic steps to unlock shareholder value. Our unmatched infrastructure and development talents provide a sound basis for an increasing flow of dividends to our shareholders.
And in the forecast, we have very visible growth supporting a 37% growth in guidance from 2010 to '12. And in the future, a very strong case for continued growth beyond the guidance period.
Over the long haul, we have a track record of doing what is right for our shareholders, employees and the environment. And we are very excited to continue to track-record, and we have a great future ahead of us that we're all excited about being a part of.
And with that, I'll turn it over to for questions.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Carl Kirst of BMO Capital.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Carl Kirst of BMO Capital.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: The first one, with respect to the higher CapEx and maybe, first here to ask on the E&P side, especially as we look at the 2012 we're moving the midpoint of $300 million, $400 million or so. What are the volumetric growth rates that we should be thinking
componenttext: The first one, with respect to the higher CapEx and maybe, first here to ask on the E&P side, especially as we look at the 2012 we're moving the midpoint of $300 million, $400 million or so. What are the volumetric growth rates that we should be thinking about with that move up in CapEx? Does that have any shift in, say for instance, the composition that has been discussed in the recent past getting to 25% of oil revenues in the next few years, et cetera?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Carl, it's Ralph. The growth rate previously in the previous guidance I believe was 3% for '11 and 7% for '12. And I think we're now at 9% for '11 and approximately 10% for '12. That's clearly an increasing CapEx primarily because of the new acquisition i
componenttext: Carl, it's Ralph. The growth rate previously in the previous guidance I believe was 3% for '11 and 7% for '12. And I think we're now at 9% for '11 and approximately 10% for '12. That's clearly an increasing CapEx primarily because of the new acquisition in the Bakken. And we are, as we mentioned, we expect over the next couple of years, in our initial press release, that we'll be switching more in 2010 from really just a very negligible amount of our revenues were coming from oil, substantially more will be coming from the well in the future as a reflection of that. I think we said in the initial press release back then, it was within the next -- by 2013 or so, I thought we'd ought to be like 25% oil revenue. So it's clearly the increase is one of our production growth is going up quite a bit the next couple of years because of the new asset and that's a reflection of the capital and also a reflection of the difference in mix we'll have from almost all gas to where about 25% of that was coming from the oil and liquids side.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then so, Ralph, that 25% then is just correlating with the new growth rates?
componenttext: And then so, Ralph, that 25% then is just correlating with the new growth rates?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, exactly, it's just a function of -- it correlates exactly what the growth rates are higher than what we previously -- in our previous guidance.
componenttext: Yes, exactly, it's just a function of -- it correlates exactly what the growth rates are higher than what we previously -- in our previous guidance.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Alan, if I could ask one of the question on -- as the other clearly is going to become more important in several different ways. I noticed we've had about $300 million for the, as you mentioned, additional processing that's coming in, in Canada. When do y
componenttext: Alan, if I could ask one of the question on -- as the other clearly is going to become more important in several different ways. I noticed we've had about $300 million for the, as you mentioned, additional processing that's coming in, in Canada. When do you think we will see it that just a matter of getting that additional capacity online, we'll see additional volumes flowing? Is that the bottleneck? Or is the fact that we also need to sign additional capacity contracts with off gas producers?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, there's a little bit of the first and a lot of the latter. The government of Alberta has been considering a subsidy for ethane recovery in the province. And, of course, that's got folks wondering and making sure that they're positioned if that does
componenttext: Well, there's a little bit of the first and a lot of the latter. The government of Alberta has been considering a subsidy for ethane recovery in the province. And, of course, that's got folks wondering and making sure that they're positioned if that does happen to take advantage of that. And so that's got things stymied a little bit at this point. And we're hoping to see an announcement on that in the not-too-distant future. So we think that'll unlock a little bit of a logjam that's existing up there right now.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: But the fact that you guys have moved that in the guidance, I guess, gives a pretty clear confidence that you think additional contracts to process more off gases coming?
componenttext: But the fact that you guys have moved that in the guidance, I guess, gives a pretty clear confidence that you think additional contracts to process more off gases coming?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're quite a ways along on that front. But we do not have signatures, that's correct.
componenttext: Yes. We're quite a ways along on that front. But we do not have signatures, that's correct.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: And lastly, with respect to olefins as a whole, we've obviously got some nice CapEx growth here in 2011, 2012. Trying to ask this in a way that doesn't touch on the restructuring. But is it something where we might see that shift at all as we take an even
componenttext: And lastly, with respect to olefins as a whole, we've obviously got some nice CapEx growth here in 2011, 2012. Trying to ask this in a way that doesn't touch on the restructuring. But is it something where we might see that shift at all as we take an even longer-term approach 2013 and beyond, i.e. the growth we see is more sort of near-term. We do that and then go more into harvest mode. Or do you see enough petrochemical related growth opportunities that the amount of CapEx we're seeing on the other sector right now, this $400 million, $500 million quite frankly could continue on for several years even beyond 2012?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think there's two ways to think about that. If you think about it in Canada, again we've got a nice nest egg there coming from our international cash flows. We've got a nice nest egg there to grow that business. And as we reported, we have $500 mi
componenttext: Well, I think there's two ways to think about that. If you think about it in Canada, again we've got a nice nest egg there coming from our international cash flows. We've got a nice nest egg there to grow that business. And as we reported, we have $500 million of cash sitting there. And we continue to add very nice cash flows in addition to that in our Canadian business. And so we're pretty well positioned there. And of course, we don't have any debt against those specific cash flows up there. So there's a lot of ways to fund that Canadian growth without dipping in to the current WMB free cash flows. But I would tell you that, that could go on for quite some time. The ability to optimize around those oil sands up there and those gas reserves could go on for quite some time, and we're extremely well positioned up there. I think we're really at the tip of the iceberg in that business. In the U.S., much smaller piece of that, obviously. But we do see a lot of opportunity to help de-bottleneck the pet chem space, not just our own, but others in the U.S. But it certainly wouldn't be as dramatic given what we know right now as the Canadian opportunities.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Lasan Johong with RBC Capital.
componenttext: Our next question will come from Lasan Johong with RBC Capital.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Alan, a delicate question, if I may. with the separation of the two businesses, it frees up a lot of room for capital redeployment at WMB. So in context of that background, would you mind commenting on kind of the M&A prospects in the U.S. and Canada for
componenttext: Alan, a delicate question, if I may. with the separation of the two businesses, it frees up a lot of room for capital redeployment at WMB. So in context of that background, would you mind commenting on kind of the M&A prospects in the U.S. and Canada for midstream and pipeline businesses and companies?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I certainly think that we'll have our eyes open for opportunities to aggressively grow the infrastructure side of the company based on our strategies. But I also would tell you that we're going to remain very disciplined as we have in the past in te
componenttext: Well, I certainly think that we'll have our eyes open for opportunities to aggressively grow the infrastructure side of the company based on our strategies. But I also would tell you that we're going to remain very disciplined as we have in the past in terms of making sure that those are accretive and makes sense for our shareholders in the long-run. So certainly, we'd tell you that we've got our eyes open to it. But we're going to remain very disciplined at the same time.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Maybe if I ask it another way, would you be prioritizing higher these kind of opportunities than you were prior to the spinoff?
componenttext: Maybe if I ask it another way, would you be prioritizing higher these kind of opportunities than you were prior to the spinoff?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we'll have more currencies likely than we've had previously. So to that degree, yes.
componenttext: Well, I think we'll have more currencies likely than we've had previously. So to that degree, yes.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: The 126 Bcfe add of reserves from acquisitions at E&P, I'm assuming that, that is what the existing amount of reserves that you bought. But doesn't reflect the potential of reserves that you think exist in the Marcellus and the Bakken, correct?
componenttext: The 126 Bcfe add of reserves from acquisitions at E&P, I'm assuming that, that is what the existing amount of reserves that you bought. But doesn't reflect the potential of reserves that you think exist in the Marcellus and the Bakken, correct?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Ralph. It is. It's really a reflection. We basically have booked a very small amount in the Marcellus as we wait for primarily the laser pipeline Susquehanna had to come on, so that is about 20 of that. And then the remaining piece of that is the
componenttext: This is Ralph. It is. It's really a reflection. We basically have booked a very small amount in the Marcellus as we wait for primarily the laser pipeline Susquehanna had to come on, so that is about 20 of that. And then the remaining piece of that is the Bakken. We have said publicly, we believe each of those on a 3P-type basis areas, each one has -- I believe the Bakken has about 1.1 Tcf if you convert that into gas equivalent opportunity and the Marcellus is about 1.2 Tcf of 3P. So we have a very small amount of that booked at this time.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: So we should expect to see that increase relatively rapidly as you see infrastructure get put into play, correct? Not necessarily the drilling but the infrastructure?
componenttext: So we should expect to see that increase relatively rapidly as you see infrastructure get put into play, correct? Not necessarily the drilling but the infrastructure?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we never really comment on where it's going forward. But we bought a lot of problem, possible reserves, and we do expect to be very successful in that aspect.
componenttext: Well, we never really comment on where it's going forward. But we bought a lot of problem, possible reserves, and we do expect to be very successful in that aspect.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll hear next from Citi's Faisel Khan.
componenttext: We'll hear next from Citi's Faisel Khan.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you can give us a little bit of an idea, I know you've talked about this in your guidance a little bit, but if I look at your ethane equities, also your NGL equity sales balance kind of over the last year or so, they're up around 10% ov
componenttext: I was wondering if you can give us a little bit of an idea, I know you've talked about this in your guidance a little bit, but if I look at your ethane equities, also your NGL equity sales balance kind of over the last year or so, they're up around 10% over last year. It looks like that trajectory should continue given the economic growth. But are there any bottlenecks in order to continue to grow that opportunity? Is there enough demand on the other end to kind of consume those barrels? Or is there something that we should be worried about in the future as we kind of reach the maximum operating capacity of the industry?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Rory Miller, I'll take that question. I think on -- there's been a lot of concern, I think, in the marketplace about ethane. I think we're pretty bullish still near term and probably midterm that there is enough creep, if you will, on the cracking
componenttext: This is Rory Miller, I'll take that question. I think on -- there's been a lot of concern, I think, in the marketplace about ethane. I think we're pretty bullish still near term and probably midterm that there is enough creep, if you will, on the cracking capacity that the additional ethane will be soaked up. So we're pretty bullish on it. We think we're in good shape through the end of the year, probably, into next year as well. We'll just have to watch that closely. But right now, looking at the forward strip for instance, it looks like that market is backward dated and probably, well under our expectation, the way we see ethane prices at the end of the year.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then if I could also just understand the opportunity in the Gulf of Mexico for you guys. I guess, when you present the potential capital expenditure opportunities midstream, one of the big parts of your pie chart is what could happen in the Gulf of Me
componenttext: And then if I could also just understand the opportunity in the Gulf of Mexico for you guys. I guess, when you present the potential capital expenditure opportunities midstream, one of the big parts of your pie chart is what could happen in the Gulf of Mexico. Because recently we've seen you guys be a part of some of the tendering for using your spar platform versus some other sort of computing technologies in the Gulf. How big is that opportunity? And when do you think we'll see some development take place on that front given your activities there?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, there's a lot of pent-up demand right now. Obviously, with the moratorium, the whole space out there has been on hold. But people have been working projects. There are a lot of projects that need to get back underway. And the BOEM, I think, has flagg
componenttext: Yes, there's a lot of pent-up demand right now. Obviously, with the moratorium, the whole space out there has been on hold. But people have been working projects. There are a lot of projects that need to get back underway. And the BOEM, I think, has flagged that they do intend to get people back to work. We're starting to see signs of that. So I think throughout the course of 2011, we are going to see a substantial improvement in terms of producers being able to get back out and get active. What that means to our GulfStar product, I think, is very positive. We do have discussions going on right now with opportunities to deploy that. Again, we don't have anything to announce yet. But we are optimistic and I would say looking forward, there's a significant backlog of opportunities we see on the horizon that we think are going to come into the marketplace over the next, say, 18 months, as people get back to work in the Gulf. So we see that as an opportunity, probably, on kind of 100% basis, which may not be the way that we invest. We may bring on partners for that business, but that's a way to scale things up rather quickly. Most of those investments with the pipeline interconnections are around $1 billion of investment each. So it is a way to move the needle.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: I was looking for this in your prepared materials, but what is the cash balance at the end of the year for you guys? And I suspect that was after the Bakken transaction.
componenttext: I was looking for this in your prepared materials, but what is the cash balance at the end of the year for you guys? And I suspect that was after the Bakken transaction.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011

componenttext: We're sized about $800 million. That's largely an international cash balance, some WPZ cash and a bit of Williams cash.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ted Durbin of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ted Durbin of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: If I can just ask about how you're thinking about the dividend. You have the raise, obviously, enough last night and then you're looking for raising next year. How should we think about the payout ratio going forward here?
componenttext: If I can just ask about how you're thinking about the dividend. You have the raise, obviously, enough last night and then you're looking for raising next year. How should we think about the payout ratio going forward here?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Don Chappel. I think you've seen our WPZ guidance. And WPZ has guided to a 6% to 10% increase in the L.P. distribution. And of course, Williams will oversee an even bigger increase in distributions by virtue of the incentive distribution reps that
componenttext: This is Don Chappel. I think you've seen our WPZ guidance. And WPZ has guided to a 6% to 10% increase in the L.P. distribution. And of course, Williams will oversee an even bigger increase in distributions by virtue of the incentive distribution reps that we hold. So when we look at the cash flows from WPZ, that are expected to come up to Williams. And that's where I think a healthy coverage ratio at WPZ, again, I think you saw at the midpoint of our guidance, the PZ coverage ratio is at about 1.2x. But then we take that into Williams and that's the primary driver of the corporate dividend. And I think you can also see from, if run through the calculations, especially X E&P, we get to a coverage ratio at Williams as well. I don't think we're prepared to speak to a coverage ratio, but we do have some coverage there and the good news is here in 2010, we're putting some of that money back in the E&P to grow the Bakken production. So we're drilling a bit beyond our cash flows to get the Bakken started up. But beyond separation, the net access cash flow is available for other opportunities, including the dividend that we spoke into.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess, kind of coming down the similar question that was asked before, I mean, how much will you think about sort of a run rate CapEx that this other segment will need whether it's growth capital, maintenance capital. Just thinking about corporate G&A.
componenttext: I guess, kind of coming down the similar question that was asked before, I mean, how much will you think about sort of a run rate CapEx that this other segment will need whether it's growth capital, maintenance capital. Just thinking about corporate G&A. How does that all factor into then what cash you could distribute out in the dividend?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: I would say right now, we don't see any significant change in the corporate G&A. Obviously, with two separate companies, we'll have some increases and we'll also look to offset that with some simplification, if you will. In terms of the other segment, aga
componenttext: I would say right now, we don't see any significant change in the corporate G&A. Obviously, with two separate companies, we'll have some increases and we'll also look to offset that with some simplification, if you will. In terms of the other segment, again, as Alan mentioned, we have about $500 million of international cash, that's really the seed money for a lot of the growth up in Canada. Beyond that, we expect to have some debt capacity and likely, in Canadian denominated debt, for the next phase of growth out there. And if we look at our credit metrics over the next several years, we should have some more debt capacity, particularly up on those Canadian assets. What that really remains in is the U.S. olefins business and that's a fairly modestly sized business today, perhaps, some expansions. But I'd say, the maintenance capital requirements are pretty modest and the growth capital requirements as you look at our forecast in terms of our U.S. cash balance are very, very modest.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: On Slide 18 there, we kind of show the domestic olefins and kind of gives you a picture for that. As you look at that, for instance, you have to recognize that that's spread over the 2011 through 2015 timeframe. So as Don said, even in the more speculativ
componenttext: On Slide 18 there, we kind of show the domestic olefins and kind of gives you a picture for that. As you look at that, for instance, you have to recognize that that's spread over the 2011 through 2015 timeframe. So as Don said, even in the more speculative picture there, fairly modest. Not that we would not like to grow that, frankly. But in terms of demand for it, this as we know is fairly modest at this point.

componenttext: If I would say it, it tends to be in the kind of 3x to 4x debt to EBITDA range. I think you can look at the agency's metrics in terms of guidelines to guide you, that's a pretty simple statement that I made. But somewhere in that zip code.

componenttextpreview: We don't have any plans to do that at this point in time. And the growth trajectory remains very robust there. We've got quite a bit of growth here in the foreseeable future domestically and so don't see any reason to reveal that complexity to our unit ho
componenttext: We don't have any plans to do that at this point in time. And the growth trajectory remains very robust there. We've got quite a bit of growth here in the foreseeable future domestically and so don't see any reason to reveal that complexity to our unit holders at this point.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think it remained an option. Option that we have in the future, and I think as Alan points out, we have so much growth right now. It's probably not a very good fit for the MLP plus the international tax issues related to it. Make it something that's mor
componenttext: I think it remained an option. Option that we have in the future, and I think as Alan points out, we have so much growth right now. It's probably not a very good fit for the MLP plus the international tax issues related to it. Make it something that's more of a long-term possibility versus anything in the rear near term.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of your decision to IPO and then spin the E&P business versus just spinning it, could you give us a background behind that decision?
componenttext: And then in terms of your decision to IPO and then spin the E&P business versus just spinning it, could you give us a background behind that decision?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: I would say that again, given the SEC rules, there's very little we can say about the transaction. I would just point to the press release. And we did had a desire to raise some IPO proceeds at the Williams level in order to pay down some debt. And contin
componenttext: I would say that again, given the SEC rules, there's very little we can say about the transaction. I would just point to the press release. And we did had a desire to raise some IPO proceeds at the Williams level in order to pay down some debt. And continue to have a very strong credit rating at Williams. And I think you've seen the notes from the ratings agencies and that's the plan.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: We're still staying in what we gave as the guidance at that time, which is a $7.5 million to $8.5 million range. But what we're seeing is now that we've taken operations on the drilling side, and we're still in the process of taking over operations on the
componenttext: We're still staying in what we gave as the guidance at that time, which is a $7.5 million to $8.5 million range. But what we're seeing is now that we've taken operations on the drilling side, and we're still in the process of taking over operations on the completion in just the normal field operations, our first few wells that we have drilled are down into the lower 30-day range. Previous owner was more in the 40- to 50-day range. So we expect to be in that $7.5 million to $8.5 million as we put on our guidance. We're pleased of what we have, as Alan mentioned, early on and this winter, there's been some, obviously, a pretty severe winters and completion delays. But on the drilling side, we're very pleased at this time. And hope to have our completions caught up at some point this year.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to jump back to the distributions and I was wondering if there's any tax shield that we should be thinking about as you receive these reasons from WPZ. Just trying to understand the dynamics there a little better.
componenttext: I just wanted to jump back to the distributions and I was wondering if there's any tax shield that we should be thinking about as you receive these reasons from WPZ. Just trying to understand the dynamics there a little better.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Jonathan, Williams pays tax on WPZ's earnings. Our proportionate share of WPZ earnings regardless of the distribution. So from a tax standpoint, we've filed a consolidated tax return and really kind of looks through the structure. So that really didn't ch
componenttext: Jonathan, Williams pays tax on WPZ's earnings. Our proportionate share of WPZ earnings regardless of the distribution. So from a tax standpoint, we've filed a consolidated tax return and really kind of looks through the structure. So that really didn't change Williams' tax position relative to WPZ business, earnings didn't change. So I think we've said that you can probably look at the distribution, the ballpark, the taxes and apply something like a 30% rate on the distribution and get into the right zip code in terms of what the effective tax rate is on those earnings.

componenttextpreview: And then just wanted to follow up on the MLP question. I know you answered about the Canadian assets not fitting into the MLP structure today. But I was just wondering, what about Grasmere, with that -- I know it could fit. But just wondering if think tha
componenttext: And then just wanted to follow up on the MLP question. I know you answered about the Canadian assets not fitting into the MLP structure today. But I was just wondering, what about Grasmere, with that -- I know it could fit. But just wondering if think that at some point, you might look to put that at WPZ?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: As I'm sure you're aware, that income is not qualified income from an MLP standpoint. However, given the size of WPZ and the scale that it's grown into, it doesn't mean that we could not at some point. But at this point, again, we've got enough growth pot
componenttext: As I'm sure you're aware, that income is not qualified income from an MLP standpoint. However, given the size of WPZ and the scale that it's grown into, it doesn't mean that we could not at some point. But at this point, again, we've got enough growth potential, we don't see a need to put that in at this time. And bring that risk to bear for some standpoint.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just lastly, I know you have plenty of capacity to increase the dividend here. Just wondering how you maybe weigh that against the opportunity to do some share repurchases and how we should be thinking about that going forward.
componenttext: Just lastly, I know you have plenty of capacity to increase the dividend here. Just wondering how you maybe weigh that against the opportunity to do some share repurchases and how we should be thinking about that going forward.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: I would say that we think the dividend is very highly valued. Obviously, we think our stock is something that's also attractive. So we'll continue to look at the options there. I would say that right now, our bias is toward dividend. We think the market r
componenttext: I would say that we think the dividend is very highly valued. Obviously, we think our stock is something that's also attractive. So we'll continue to look at the options there. I would say that right now, our bias is toward dividend. We think the market really appreciates the dividend growth being kind of a long-term cash flow stream. But we'll continue to look at all the options.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011

componenttext: Just finally, for Ralph, I noticed the mention of the Niobrara is under review. Just wondering if maybe you could give us a little bit of color around that. And what your intentions are there? And maybe this, I assume, is the gas Niobrara?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, basically, what we're doing at this point is the gas Niobrara and that's in the Piceance Basin. We have some opportunities that we've mentioned previously that we're looking just in our normal acreage that we have to test some of the Niobrara in the
componenttext: Yes, basically, what we're doing at this point is the gas Niobrara and that's in the Piceance Basin. We have some opportunities that we've mentioned previously that we're looking just in our normal acreage that we have to test some of the Niobrara in the Piceance.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll move next to Craig Shere of Tuohy Brothers Investment Research.
componenttext: We'll move next to Craig Shere of Tuohy Brothers Investment Research.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Alan, you commented during the call already and also, I believe, back in November during some of your investor meetings that you'd certainly like to grow the U.S. olefins business, particularly to the degree it could service an offtaker and reduce some of
componenttext: Alan, you commented during the call already and also, I believe, back in November during some of your investor meetings that you'd certainly like to grow the U.S. olefins business, particularly to the degree it could service an offtaker and reduce some of the risk for ethane price volatility from PZ. But you kind of mentioned today that you don't necessarily see a lot of demand there, even though plastics pricing is going up worldwide and there continues to be the ethane advantage versus alternative feedstock. Can you comment on that and the ability to drive down that coverage ratio that Don referred to at 1.2x?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Craig, thank you for the question actually because it gives me an opportunity to clarify that. When I spoke to demand, I wasn't speaking really lack of demand on the pet chem side, because as you know, ethylene derivative products like polyethylene are ve
componenttext: Craig, thank you for the question actually because it gives me an opportunity to clarify that. When I spoke to demand, I wasn't speaking really lack of demand on the pet chem side, because as you know, ethylene derivative products like polyethylene are very advantaged here in the U.S. relative to the rest of the world that primarily uses naphtha to produce that product. And so as we have continued low natural gas prices here, we continue to have a lot of opportunity in that regard. And we are very excited about that space. I would just say that we are also seeing a lot of interest by the pet chem space in moving upstream as well. And so there may be a way to reduce risk to our portfolio and lead people better more in the business of ethylene-derivative business. And the exports of those products doing their expertise. And us doing the upstream in perhaps in a way that partners with those parties and reduces our risk. So that's why the capital isn't real large in that space right now as there's perhaps some partnering opportunities that give us visibility all the way through the polyethylene for instance. But doesn't require us to put up a tremendous amount of capital in that space.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: And do you see the de-risking at PZ coming from long-term contracts that are less variable based, more fixed? Or simply linked more to a percentage of oil that can be hedged?
componenttext: And do you see the de-risking at PZ coming from long-term contracts that are less variable based, more fixed? Or simply linked more to a percentage of oil that can be hedged?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Either one and both of those avenues are being pursued. So I would say probably, more likely, for longer term deals, it would be something tied to crude oil.
componenttext: Either one and both of those avenues are being pursued. So I would say probably, more likely, for longer term deals, it would be something tied to crude oil.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ralph, two quick questions. I don't know if you'll answer the second one. But on the first one, it looks like, if I understood your answer to Carl's question, and I'm doing the math right on Slide 11 with the how much you'll be spending on the Bakken, it
componenttext: Ralph, two quick questions. I don't know if you'll answer the second one. But on the first one, it looks like, if I understood your answer to Carl's question, and I'm doing the math right on Slide 11 with the how much you'll be spending on the Bakken, it looks like your CapEx for gas has not come down much, even though the gas strip is somewhat meaningfully lower than what was assumed in the third quarter guidance, which I think was $5 at that time. And the production guidance in 2011 doesn't seem to show much decline on the gas expectation. So the first question is, can you comment about your thinking and plans in terms of gassy CapEx investment relative to changes in commodity prices? And the second question is, whether as part of the broader family or on your own, I just wonder how much the credit street gives you for the 69% ownership in Apco and what you can do to kind of get that story out there?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, on the first side, we are basically holding this rig count we talked about for the gas side in November which is about 11 rigs in the Piceance and three in the Marcellus Shale growing this year to the approximately six, probably at the end of the ye
componenttext: Well, on the first side, we are basically holding this rig count we talked about for the gas side in November which is about 11 rigs in the Piceance and three in the Marcellus Shale growing this year to the approximately six, probably at the end of the year in the Marcellus. We did drop three rigs from the Barnett, we're down to one and we have changed that around somewhat. We still think in those areas we're drilling in, which is primarily the Piceance and the Marcellus on the gas side, we fell very good about our returns there. So we're comfortable with that. And going forward, obviously, as we get our hands more and more around the Bakken side of the world, to the extent we can build our inventory permitting, get our staff out there, we will probably look to when the time is right to shift those resources from the gassy to the oily side. So we have -- at November call, you might recall, we did drop about 10 rigs from what we had previously thought would be doing on the gas side. So we've already taken a pretty big cut at that. As for Apco, we continue to have a number of successes in Apco that you've seen in the past, and we'll just be able to talk about that somewhat when we go through the process. But you've seen that we have some slides out there now to talk about the concessions we have. And both in Argentina and some concessions in Colombia and that's just something we'll be able to talk about when we get through this process.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll move on to Kevin Smith of Raymond James.
componenttext: We'll move on to Kevin Smith of Raymond James.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: In the past, I guess, you guys have talked about the communication flow being a consolidated company, having all these different aspects and how you're able to jointly develop projects and the synergies from that. I don't know if we're getting too sensiti
componenttext: In the past, I guess, you guys have talked about the communication flow being a consolidated company, having all these different aspects and how you're able to jointly develop projects and the synergies from that. I don't know if we're getting too sensitive, but how do you see communication flow past the breakup?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll take that. Now first of all, certainly has been particularly between Midstream and E&P. A lot of opportunities for Midstream to kind of be ahead, and as well for Midstream to help the E&P group get fair value for their liquids as well. And so o
componenttext: Well, I'll take that. Now first of all, certainly has been particularly between Midstream and E&P. A lot of opportunities for Midstream to kind of be ahead, and as well for Midstream to help the E&P group get fair value for their liquids as well. And so on both fronts, I think, there's been benefit there. So I wouldn't sit and deny that. Certainly through the IPO process, and as long as it's a controlled subsidiary, there's no reason that we would lose that. But ultimately, in the spin, we will have to work hard to maintain a good relationship and that certainly our goal as a management team right now is to maintain a good relationship and continue to be able to enjoy that to the degree we can legally.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011

componenttext: Are there any gathering contracts or anything that will have to be kind of split out or is all that stuff already separate?

componenttextpreview: Because we have WPZ holding most of our Domestic Midstream business, most of that is squared away pretty well. So not any major deals at all, it'll be a little bit to clean up here and there, but for the most part, it's taken care of because we already ha
componenttext: Because we have WPZ holding most of our Domestic Midstream business, most of that is squared away pretty well. So not any major deals at all, it'll be a little bit to clean up here and there, but for the most part, it's taken care of because we already had the separate WPZ entity.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: When do you think you'll be able to talk about the Bakken wells that you're drilling now?
componenttext: When do you think you'll be able to talk about the Bakken wells that you're drilling now?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Ralph. We probably we'll have, I would guess in our next last call, some more update on that. We closed the deal December 21, have just now, as I mentioned, taken over the drilling side, and we have our staff in place. We've been blessed in the ne
componenttext: This is Ralph. We probably we'll have, I would guess in our next last call, some more update on that. We closed the deal December 21, have just now, as I mentioned, taken over the drilling side, and we have our staff in place. We've been blessed in the new Marcellus team and also in the new Bakken team that we've been able to pull from resources in the Piceance, the Powder and the Barnett and bring a lot of expertise to each of those teams. So we're in the game right now. And I would guess that we'll start giving some updates at the next call and everything we've seen so far is what we thought would be. So we're very pleased with that. The only thing we have, as Alan mentioned, I mentioned, where we have a little bit of completion backlog as I think most of the industry does up there. But with our relationships with our vendors nationwide, we think we'll be able to overcome that delay.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011

Again as I mentioned, we feel like in the current, we're certainly delivering in our forecast, we've got great growth, identifiable growth. And in an longer-term future, we remain very excited about the prospects. So thank you again for joining us this morning.
