componenttext: Ted, I think stock buyback will certainly be in the cards. I think, again, we're blessed with a lot of very attractive investment opportunities so I think it'll be continuously weighing the potential reinvestment opportunities versus stock buyback. And again, if it wasn't more sustainable, cash flow stream and dividend will be the likely outcome.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Next we'll go to Tim Schneider with Citi.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's Faisel Khan from Citi Group. Alan, going back to the Canadian business for a second. How do you guys go about capturing some of the existing barrels in operation in Canada. You guys put together a slide, where you show the barrels you guys are curren
componenttext: It's Faisel Khan from Citi Group. Alan, going back to the Canadian business for a second. How do you guys go about capturing some of the existing barrels in operation in Canada. You guys put together a slide, where you show the barrels you guys are currently recovering right now else and the NGL and olefins volumes in Canada and the future barrels that are coming online but there's this large yellow sliver that still can't be captured. What's your status in negotiation in capturing some of those barrels and moving some of those projects forward and where are you in that timeline?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. Great, great question, Faisel. That yellow is -- basically represents the barrels from the existing upgraders as you picked up on, which is the CNRL and Sin crude. And we're pretty far along. These are big projects and complicated and things don't mo
componenttext:
Yes. Great, great question, Faisel. That yellow is -- basically represents the barrels from the existing upgraders as you picked up on, which is the CNRL and Sin crude. And we're pretty far along. These are big projects and complicated and things don't move real briskly on that front but we're confident in ultimately -- the liquids being lifted from those streams, it really doesn't make any sense at all not to because it produces higher emissions in the air, which is obviously a critical issue as well as a tremendous amount of value being burnt there as that gas today is being consumed in boilers. So there's a real big opportunity to get that and then your question that just boils down to who gets it extracts it. 
So I have great confidence in that yellow being captured. And I would just tell you, I think we are very well-positioned to capture that and negotiations are ongoing on both fronts. I would tell you the CNRL negotiations are ahead of the Sin Crude [ph] negotiations. That about as much as I can share with you on that at this point.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011

componenttext: And can you give us an update on your product in the deep gulf and where are you in negotiation with customers on that particular product for that solution?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Rory. I'll take that question. That's actually a wet dream as far as we're calling those projects. I think there was an announcement that came out last week from Gulf Marine and mentioned they'd entered into an agreement with us to build a sparkle
componenttext:
This is Rory. I'll take that question. That's actually a wet dream as far as we're calling those projects. I think there was an announcement that came out last week from Gulf Marine and mentioned they'd entered into an agreement with us to build a sparkle [ph] in the Gulf of Mexico and that is correct. We have a letter of agreement signed with a couple of producers in the Gulf. We are not in the liberty right now to reveal who those players are but that is in place. The letter of agreement includes a reimbursement provision so we can start spending money today along the timelines on major construction contracts, contracts in anticipation of definitive agreements. 
We're looking at probably a third quarter signing of those definitive agreements. That is moving ahead. That will be our first GulfStar project. I think we mentioned in the last call, the connection pipeline, those are around $1 billion a piece and this particular project, we're looking at bringing in JV Partners so thinking all the guidance numbers that we're giving capital is about half of that number. 
That project is been in the works for a long time. We've been able to get much of the engineering, much of the design work and much of the critical thinking done on that product, done ahead of time. So we're not parallel-pathing a lot of engineering and construction at the same time. We think that's going to reduce a lot of construction risk on that project and we're very excited about that. In terms of more details on the counterparties, that's probably going to be more of a third quarter type of announcement.

componenttext: If I can ask a question on down the E&P operation, is that still a possibility? Or is that off limits right now? I'm just trying to get your guys' idea of how that is taking place.

componenttext: This is Ralph. There are a couple of things we're doing. Obviously we're and the loan concession. We continue to do well in our major positions down there which is the Entre Roman [ph], the Bahamas Pallum [ph], Agua de Marga [ph]. We also are in the process of testing some re-completion in that area of the Bottom Northending Shale [ph] and we're just in the early stage of that. It's an old vertical well so we're testing and we have a substantial amount of acreage that is close to the Bakken Oil Play and we look forward to continue to test that acreage as we move through. Early on, we'll just be testing some vertical wells and then we'll do some horizontals so you'll find the areas that you like.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Holly, basically it's a combination of radion laser and also some radion infrastructure in the Westmoreland Center County. And those, the Westmoreland Center Counties are in the process -- they will be fixed here, most of that, in the very near future. So
componenttext:
Holly, basically it's a combination of radion laser and also some radion infrastructure in the Westmoreland Center County. And those, the Westmoreland Center Counties are in the process -- they will be fixed here, most of that, in the very near future. So about half of our 30 subwells that we're waiting on completion in that area so we look forward to those coming on. In fact, we had 2 wells come on. And probably Eushack area [ph] just over the weekend. 
So we do believe, as we said in the -- on our slides that production should ramp up rapidly as we alleviate the concerns of the transportation, particularly the laser pipeline you would have total volumes -- and just supplemented by end of the year 70 million a day so we look for a rapid ramp up. 
Our wells, our rigs right now are operating in the -- 1 and Susquehanna and the others are 1 in Columbia County and the Grasmere and Westmoreland clear built counties.

componenttext: And then just maybe a bigger picture question for Alan. Do you guys have an internal forecast at this point of what you expect the ramping ethane supply say maybe between now and then 2014?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: We don't have a specific number. We watched that and we watched that balance very closely but we do not have a specific volume forecast for that so to answer your question is no. I would tell you that we remain pretty confident because as I said earlier i
componenttext:
We don't have a specific number. We watched that and we watched that balance very closely but we do not have a specific volume forecast for that so to answer your question is no. I would tell you that we remain pretty confident because as I said earlier in the creek that will go on in all of these facilities that are either heavy crackers, continue proficiency been gained in that area and I think we'll see that for the next couple of years and again as he mentioned, projects like our own at Grasmere. So I think we'll continue to see that and then I think those big projects in the 3 to 4-year timeframe, those big projects will start to kick in. Some of those projects that have been announced are very large scale projects and will take a long time. 
In between those 2 things, there's also going to be expansions to existing facilities that will be rather significant and I think the current margin environment and the confidence in crude to gas right now is going to continue to have people investing in that space as well. And so I think it's rare that we have on the ethane and ethylene side, ethylene cracking, it's rare that we see the 2 things build at the same time. But because the margins in this environment, the margins are so strong in both spaces, I think we'll continue to see the ethanes supplies build and I think we'll continue to see the ethane cracking capabilities build as well. And there may be a few rocky steps here and there but right now, this trajectory look very good.

componenttext: A couple of quick questions of derisking from a commodity risk standpoint. Alen, you've been talking for some months about the possibility of finding long-term ethane offtakers with the petro chems, but in some of the more recent earnings calls, industry peers commented something similar to what you just said. It's not overly tight, it's not overly loose, but the petro chem's key sufficient supply were no immediate need for long-term bilateral contracting. Can you comment on this or whether you see different line of thinking from the petrochems as some of them contemplate some of these larger greenfield construction projects of worldscale crackers.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: I certainly think the folks that we talk to, and of course, we have own advantage vantage point via our own PetChem space their. But I certainly think that the investors in that space recognize that there is very high margins right now available to them a
componenttext:
I certainly think the folks that we talk to, and of course, we have own advantage vantage point via our own PetChem space their. But I certainly think that the investors in that space recognize that there is very high margins right now available to them and I think they are in the leery in seeing the demand get overheated
[Audio Gap]
that are obviously, very concerned about long-term supply and I think the effort that I think is the smart decision for the industry to look to look to the total pie between gas and crude and that comes back to gas polyethylene or other ethylene derivatives. And to figure out how they can assure themselves a portion of that margin that allows them to invest in infrastructure going forward that's got more stable in earnings behind it, rather than a winner and a loser accross that chain but figuring out how that margin will be shared in a way that allows both parties to invest going forward in a very adequate return that exists out there. 
And I hope, I certainly think, that the current margin environment in both those sectors doesn't lead to arrogance that will cause people to forget the past. And certainly, the folks we're talking to, anyway, and are interested in working with, I don't think that's the case.

componenttext:
I would say were up against those discussions and it's kind of hard to call the counterparty moves on those. I could tell you there's nothing imminent at this point in time and we would certainly have liked to work to be there we certainly have nothing at this point in time. But again, I think the motives are strong for the players and we'll continue to push in that direction. 
Obviously, 1 of the options we have is to do similar arrangements with our own ethylene cracking and look to margin sharing at the MB level so those are the kind of things that keep us from being too soft in our negotiations as our ability to do it ourselves there at Grasmere facility.

componenttext: You know, that's starting to be explored by folks starting to see a lot of people that are exploiting their contacts in India and China and places like that where the domain continues to grow and so I would keep tuned to that space and I'll tell you that's where a lot of the air traffic is right now is between India and China in the PetChem space and a little bit of South America as well with people wanting to make sure that they can shore up those markets and have some risk reduction in those forward-looking markets out there. So there is a lot going on but it's brand-new and most of those, a lot of that buyers on that end aren't used to doing these longer-term structured contracts so even though there's a desire and a need there, there really hasn't been a blueprint there in the past. So there's new grand being broken in that area but you're spot on with where the thinking is going in that area.

componenttextpreview: This is Don Chappell. I would say we just don't foresee a situation in which it's likely that PZ is going to build cash since we have such abundant growth opportunities. The excess earnings will just be re-invested, which will reduce our needs to go to ca
componenttext: This is Don Chappell. I would say we just don't foresee a situation in which it's likely that PZ is going to build cash since we have such abundant growth opportunities. The excess earnings will just be re-invested, which will reduce our needs to go to capital markets to raise capital at PZ. I would say the margin PZ becomes more self-funding, not to say the plant outside financing but all that excess cash to the extent that it is at a level -- it's based on margins that are leveled -- we don't think our prudent to build into distributions so we don't see idle cash sitting at PZ at all.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: I say it's a function of business mix and we're continuing to slowly add more and more key business in the Midstream business not to say that we're not adding commodity exposures as well, but proportionately, we're adding -- focused on adding a bit more o
componenttext:
I say it's a function of business mix and we're continuing to slowly add more and more key business in the Midstream business not to say that we're not adding commodity exposures as well, but proportionately, we're adding -- focused on adding a bit more on the fee side than we are on the commodity side. So we expect our key business to decrease as a percentage of the total, which will enable us to, over time, comp a lower coverage margin and it's a function of how comfortable are we with margins. 
So I think it depends where we are in the range and what moment in time but we'd like to see that drift down. I think right now, we're looking at 1.2x coverage under something that might have been more like the beginning of the year margins versus what we're seeing today.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to you Williams Companies First Quarter 2011 Earnings Release Conference. At this time, for opening remarks and introduction, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Travis Campbell, Head of Investor Relations. Please go
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to you Williams Companies First Quarter 2011 Earnings Release Conference. At this time, for opening remarks and introduction, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Travis Campbell, Head of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everybody. Welcome to our First Quarter 2011 Earnings Call. As always, thanks for your interest in the company. As you no doubt know, we released our results yesterday after the market closed. Also yesterday, Alan, using a few sli
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, everybody. Welcome to our First Quarter 2011 Earnings Call. As always, thanks for your interest in the company. As you no doubt know, we released our results yesterday after the market closed. Also yesterday, Alan, using a few slides, had some commentary about the results, our increased guidance and our growth opportunities. That audio commentaries and slides are available on the website, and because of that review yesterday, we'll not be reviewing the slides again this morning. So on our website, williams.com, you should be able to find a number of things that were posted yesterday afternoon. The first, the earnings presentation with the audio commentary by Alan. Second, the data book that contains the usual information made available every quarter. Third, the press release of the first quarter results. Fourth, our analyst package. And finally, a podcast of Alan's remarks yesterday. 
Also for your information. The first quarter 10-Q will be filed today. Because we reviewed these items yesterday, I expect the call today will be very brief and we'll get very quickly with your questions. In a minute, Alan Armstrong, our President and CEO will make some general comments, after which, we'll open the lines for questions. 
Be aware, as always, all of our business heads are here and available to respond to your questions after Alan's remarks. Here with me are Ralph Hill, who heads up the E&P Company; Rory Miller, who oversees the Midstream Company; and Randy Bernard, who heads up the gas pipeline. Also, Don Chappel, the CFO is here as well. 
As most of you are aware, last Friday, we announced that our wholly owned subsidiary, WPX Energy, Inc., filed a registration statement related to the proposed IPO of its common stock. It has a security law restriction, we will not be commenting at all on WPX Energy Inc. today. 
There are forward-looking statements on Slide 2 and 3 and disclaimer on oil and gas reserves on Slide 4, at yesterday's presentation. Those are also included in the data book. They're important and integral to the company and you should review those. 
Also, there are non-GAAP numbers included in these various presentations. Those have all been reconciled back to Generally Accepted Accounting Principles and their reconciliation schedules are also available. So with that, I'll turn it over to Alan.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. Good morning and thanks for joining us this morning. I'll just very briefly capture the highlights and key notes on what was put out as in recording yesterday and in the slide material. First of all, we're very excited to tell you we're raising gui
componenttext:
Great. Good morning and thanks for joining us this morning. I'll just very briefly capture the highlights and key notes on what was put out as in recording yesterday and in the slide material. First of all, we're very excited to tell you we're raising guidance, and this is based on both higher crude price expectations. We are now at $95 midpoint for '11 and '12 crude. And of course, that's still well below the hoard market and current pricing for crude. And current NGL margins, of course, are being lifted on that. And in fact, current NGL margins are actually just beyond the high end of range of what we have posted right now. 
Also, we have greater confidence on timing and performance on a number of new projects that are going to add to the balance in 2011. So we are raising guidance for both '11 and '12 and you can see the details of that now at a -- our midpoint for '11 is now $1.55 per share on an adjusted earnings basis. 
In the current quarter, we had mixed results to combine and produce a very solid quarter. Our gas gathering and production volumes were negatively impacted by severe winter weather primarily in the Rockies and the Bakken. With the Bakken receiving near record snowfalls. And of course, low natural gas prices also grow low quarter-over-quarter results in E&P. 
However, our Midstream Canada and Olefins segment came through and posted a record quarter that help to mitigate the weakness in the gas prices. And our Gas Pipe segment also came through with a strong quarter. 
As we look into the second quarter, we are very excited about how our volumes have rebounded and conditions are currently very good for tremendous earnings results for the balance of 2011. Looking to the balance of the year, we now expect our midpoint, as I stated earlier, EPS to be $1.55 and we're going to hit now just some of the key factors that we expect to drive this even better performance for the balance of the year. 
First of all, our operating volumes have really rebounded in all of our areas. We expect the balance of the year to be much better as the fruits of our labor in both the Marcellus and the Bakken begin to take hold both on E&P side and in the Marcellus on the WPZ Midstream side. Also, we had some major maintenance to get through in the first quarter at our big opal plant, which is the largest single contributor to our NGL equity volumes. 
Secondly, a new projects that we are expecting -- first of all, Perdido Norte project really will be a powerful contributor to earnings in the last half of the year and not so really dependent on permitting out there as much as some continued topside work that Shell is doing on their big platform that feeds both our oil gathering, our gas gathering and our Marcum [ph] processing plant. That -- and of all those facilities serving the Western Deepwater Gulf of Mexico. So we're really looking forward to seeing those volumes start to ramp up and we have confidence in that happening for the balance of the year. 
Also, our Transco Pipeline just recently placed into service 2 new projects that will combine to generate over $30 million in additional profits for the balance of the year. And then finally the Marcellus, which is really infrastructure constraint on many fronts right now, will benefit from a lot of work that E&P did in getting a lot of small gathering systems in the field to certain new production in those areas as well as the laser pipeline which -- and our very own Springville lateral, which we expect to begin in the third quarter. So a lot of things going on in the Marcellus, on the infrastructure front, some of which will directly impact our production and, of course, others that will drive earnings at the WPZ level. 
Third on margins. We anticipate continued strong unit NGL margins and olefins margins. Our current forecast in margins for NGLs are really below what we are currently experiencing and if you've noticed, we've really seen a nice shift up in ethane and as well as the heavier products continue to provide really record level margins. 
However, we also know that things can change pretty fast in this arena so we are only raising our oil prices on to the $95 and we are holding back on our NGL crude ratio assumptions below what we're currently experiencing. 
On the olefins margin side, we continue to expect robust margins on this on the back of high crude oil because the rest of the world is really dependent on olefin products that are produced from crude oil, of course, and we continue to see growing demand for olefin derivative products outside the U.S. So we're really -- in the past, the U.S. techia [ph] market was fairly dependent on the U.S. economy and it's really moved offshore right now in terms of what we're depending on. 
We, of course, cannot say much at all about the spin off of our E&P segment, to be known as WPX Energy. I can tell you that the recent S-1 filing is spot on with what we told you to expect in the last earnings call. I can also speak to the positive impact that we expect to see at WMB. WMB is going to be one of the top interviewed infrastructure companies in the nation and it is going to be better-positioned than any that I'm aware of in delivering reliable growing dividends. 
It will be investment grade and it will have the power of the increasing incentive distribution rights of the Williams Partners GP and this is going to allow for continued growth and free cash flows, and providing those of you available for dividends without dilution or financing expenses at the WMB level. 
So the clear and transparent growth that WPZ should provide confidence regarding our continued ability to grow distributions at the PZ level and we have already declared a 60% increase for the WMB June dividend, and are targeting a 10% to 15% increase in dividend for the June 2012 WMB dividend. And of course these targets were set before the latest increase in guidance at both PZ and MB. 
So overall, we're very excited about the amount of value we expect to generate in the foreseeable future for our WMB shareholders and we really are sitting at the right place, at the right time, with the right assets, the right experience and a great financial position to rapidly expand our business' earnings power. And with that, we'll turn this over for questions.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Carl Kirst with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Carl Kirst with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Nice results and certainly we appreciate the streamlined version here. Alan, maybe if I can start just on the olefin margins, and certainly we've seen a good deal of new announcements to Dow, CP Chem, Formosa, everyone looking to ramp up ethylene producti
componenttext: Nice results and certainly we appreciate the streamlined version here. Alan, maybe if I can start just on the olefin margins, and certainly we've seen a good deal of new announcements to Dow, CP Chem, Formosa, everyone looking to ramp up ethylene production in the Gulf Coast. And I'm trying to figure out with respect to guys wherein you guys are trying to get a larger market share. Is that something where their interests should help where there's more opportunity maybe to find someone with an offtake or are you finding more sort of direct competition as overall ethylene expansion perhaps, ramps?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Carl, for some reason we're having a really difficult time hearing you but let me paraphrase what I thought I heard you asking and hopefully you remind me out if I didn't hear that right with for some reason our audio in this end is breaking up. I think t
componenttext:
Carl, for some reason we're having a really difficult time hearing you but let me paraphrase what I thought I heard you asking and hopefully you remind me out if I didn't hear that right with for some reason our audio in this end is breaking up. I think the question was around the -- what we expect in terms of the increase for demand in the Pet Chem space and recognizing the new announcements from Dow and Chevron, Philips and some of the new announced Formosa, some of the new announcements on the pet chem side.  We are -- and I think another question around what we would do with the guys -- first of all on the ethane side, I think that we're pleased to see the big pet chems continuing to see the same opportunity we see in terms of being able to export ethylene derivative products and having a very low-cost feedstock here in the U.S. to continue to provide that. And so I think it's really going to be a matter of timing in terms of when those facilities, come up versus when the ethane shows up. But I will tell you that it is going to take a lot of the ethane projects and ethane supplies aren't going to show up tomorrow either. There's a lot of infrastructure required to get that ethane in place as well. So I think it's going to be a matter of how those things show up. 
But on balance, it looks pretty good from our vantage points in terms of the demand picking up with the available supply. And I would tell you that there's also going to be a lot of interim small projects. We announced our own small project there and we had guys were running, we've spent $18 million and got a small I think a 3,000 to 5,000-barrel a day increase in ethane demand there. And there's going to be a lot of those kind of projects that continue to come out and what used to be referred to as refinery tree. We're going to see be in the pet chem space as well because the margins are absolutely there and so I think those short-term kind of increases that people can squeeze out of their facilities, they're going to be doing. So I think -- hopefully that answered your question. I apologize, we couldn't quite hear it on this end.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Mainly, I was trying to figure out if they increase from the big pet chem guys would be an opportunity for Grasmere, IE: they would be an offtake of Grasmere or if its direct competition to Grasmere.
componenttext: Mainly, I was trying to figure out if they increase from the big pet chem guys would be an opportunity for Grasmere, IE: they would be an offtake of Grasmere or if its direct competition to Grasmere.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Those plans really are, at least what's been announced for the most part, is direct competition was Grasmere in terms of producing ethylene. But I would tell you that beyond the ethylene, obviously, is derivatives like polyethylene and ethylene oxide, eth
componenttext: Those plans really are, at least what's been announced for the most part, is direct competition was Grasmere in terms of producing ethylene. But I would tell you that beyond the ethylene, obviously, is derivatives like polyethylene and ethylene oxide, ethylene glycol and those derivatives are a lot less capital intensive. The facilities required for that are a lot less capital-intensive and we're pretty well-positioned there at Grasmere. There's a lot of growing derivative demand there at Grasmere and we're very well-positioned to be able to deliver against that and we certainly have a lot of conversations going with folks that are wanting to expand the offtake.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011

componenttext: Great, and then one of the question if I could just with respect to Natural Gas Liquids production. I know there was a mention of a people contract that shifted a percent of proceeds. I could understand why your equity production may have been down slightly but from sort of the gross NGLs produce, I was surprised to see that sequentially off from fourth quarter and didn't know if you could maybe comment as to where you saw that going for the rest of the year.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Carl, that's true, we are down first quarter. Other than the Exxon contract -- excuse me, some of the contracts and issues that we have out there, that's a big part of staff down in production. But the other items, I would say, were part of severe winter
componenttext: Carl, that's true, we are down first quarter. Other than the Exxon contract -- excuse me, some of the contracts and issues that we have out there, that's a big part of staff down in production. But the other items, I would say, were part of severe winter weather. We were down significantly in volumes, springs and in 4 quarters. So that has pretty big impact on our total production and of course, our equity and NGL balance as well. We also had some major maintenance that is underway at opal and that's has been finished. So we expect to see volumes in the second quarter back on the growth trajectory that we had planned and forecast.

But I'm just wondering if you would expect to see the same returns on that or what's the variability might be on the returns if you were to add on to that, have a greater processing?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: The opportunities there and/or returns there probably will remain the same. I will tell you that I was kind of put them into maybe 4 different baskets of opportunities up there. And if you look at our slides, I think it's Slide 18 in our package, you'll s
componenttext: The opportunities there and/or returns there probably will remain the same. I will tell you that I was kind of put them into maybe 4 different baskets of opportunities up there. And if you look at our slides, I think it's Slide 18 in our package, you'll see there we've got some of the segment profit, first year segment profit of those projects versus the capital shown there and you'll see, for instance, the first category I would put is on optimization projects like our BB splitter, and you'll see there that's about a 3x cash flow kind of project. We invested $52 million in our ranges, $15 million to $20 million in segment profits for the first year there.  And so those kind of projects will be very high returns like that. The Boreal pipeline, you'll see, is quite a bit lower return and part of that is just because we were building for capacity for the future and all you see there is just the first-year volumes before these additional projects come on. But I would expect those kind of projects to be in the low teens kind of returns for those pipeline kind of projects. And then the upgrader projects where we're actually going in and building a new upgraders will be a matter of negotiation but driven by a very high propylene margins so there's quite a bit of opportunity there for us to capture and it really boils down to how much we share with the upgrader and we're in very good competitive position their and that we got the pipeline now and the fractionator, red water. But those will be probably in the high teens kind of returns.  And then the ethane recovery project that we did with Nova, not going to comment on that in terms where that return is, but you can see what we expect for our first-year profit on that versus the capital investment on that and you'll see that's about a little lower over of 5 multiples in terms of what we're getting from that project. So I think that gives you a pretty good range of our expectations in that area and we're certainly anxious to get more of that business up there.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011

componenttext: Okay. And then my other question was just -- if you look the dividend at WMB and I appreciate the language that you expect strong increases beyond 2012. You raised the guidance at WPZ olefins and Canada are all doing well. So there's lot of cash that's going to be coming out of WMB. I'm just wondering if you can comment on where you might see the growth in the dividend, whether it's even higher even in 2012 or as we go past 2012.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ted, this is Don Chappel. I'll take a stab at the first year again. A lot of the upgrade in our guidance is related to very strong commodity price and we certainly don't count on that when we set WPC distribution and count on that for our Williams dividen
componenttext: Ted, this is Don Chappel. I'll take a stab at the first year again. A lot of the upgrade in our guidance is related to very strong commodity price and we certainly don't count on that when we set WPC distribution and count on that for our Williams dividends. So we really look at a much lower price margin environment as we think about WPC distributions and the Williams dividend. So that will really guide our thinking but even at that level, I think the 10% to 15% that we provided for guidance in '12 and strong growth beyond is still, we believe, is a conservative view of what we can accomplish. So we'll continue to look at it. We certainly appreciate that our stock price will, in large part, be driven by our ability to pay an increase to dividend and we'll remain very focused on that. So let's say, stay tuned beyond that.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ted, I think stock buyback will certainly be in the cards. I think, again, we're blessed with a lot of very attractive investment opportunities so I think it'll be continuously weighing the potential reinvestment opportunities versus stock buyback. And ag
componenttext: Ted, I think stock buyback will certainly be in the cards. I think, again, we're blessed with a lot of very attractive investment opportunities so I think it'll be continuously weighing the potential reinvestment opportunities versus stock buyback. And again, if it wasn't more sustainable, cash flow stream and then dividend would be the likely outcome.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's Faisel Khan from Citigroup. Alan, on the -- going back to the Canadian business for a second. How do you guys go about capturing some of the existing barrels in operation in Canada. You guys have put together a slide, where you show the barrels you g
componenttext: It's Faisel Khan from Citigroup. Alan, on the -- going back to the Canadian business for a second. How do you guys go about capturing some of the existing barrels in operation in Canada. You guys have put together a slide, where you show the barrels you guys are currently recovering right now in this individuality [ph]  NGL and olefins volumes in Canada and the future barrels that are coming online but there's this large kind of yellow sliver that still can be captured. What's your status in negotiation in kind of capturing some of those barrels and moving some of those projects forward and where are you in that timeline?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. Great, great question, Faisel. That yellow is -- basically represents the barrels from the existing upgraders as you picked up on, which is CNRL and sin crude. And we're pretty far along. These are big projects and complicated and things don't move r
componenttext:
Yes. Great, great question, Faisel. That yellow is -- basically represents the barrels from the existing upgraders as you picked up on, which is CNRL and sin crude. And we're pretty far along. These are big projects and complicated and things don't move real briskly on that front but we're confident in ultimately -- the liquids being lifted from those streams, it really doesn't make any sense at all not to because it produces higher emissions in the air, which is obviously a critical issue as well. There's a tremendous amount of value being burnt there as that gas today is being consumed in boilers. So there's a real big opportunity to get that and then the real question just boils down to who gets it and extracts it. 
So I have great confidence in that yellow being captured. And I would just tell you, I think we are very well-positioned to capture that and negotiations are ongoing on both fronts. I would tell you the CNRL negotiations are ahead of the sin crude negotiations. That's about as much as I can care to share with you on that at this point.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Rory Miller. I'll take that question. That's actually a wet dreams as far as that we're calling those projects. I think there was an announcement that came out last week from Gulf Marine and mentioned they'd entered into an agreement with us to bu
componenttext: This is Rory Miller. I'll take that question. That's actually a wet dreams as far as that we're calling those projects. I think there was an announcement that came out last week from Gulf Marine and mentioned they'd entered into an agreement with us to build a sparkle [ph]  In the Gulf of Mexico and that is correct. We have a letter of agreement signed with a couple of producers in the Gulf. We are not in the liberty right now to reveal who those players are but that is in place. The letter of agreement includes a reimbursement provision so we can start spending money today along the timelines on major construction contracts, live contracts in anticipation of definitive agreements.  We're looking at probably a third quarter signing of those definitive agreements. So that is moving ahead. That will be our first GulfStar project. I think we mentioned in the last call, the connection pipeline, those are around $1 billion a piece and on this particular project, we're looking at bringing in JV partners so I'm thinking all the guidance numbers that we're giving, the capital is about half of that number. So that project is been in the works for a long time. We've been able to get much of the engineering, much of the design work and much of the critical thinking done on that product, done ahead of time. So that we're not parallel-pathing a lot of engineering and construction at the same time. So we think that's going to reduce a lot of the construction risk on that project and we're very excited about that. So in terms of more details, those on the counterparties, that's probably going to be more of a third quarter type of announcement.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011

componenttext: Okay, got you. And I wonder if I could ask a question on the E&P operation, is that a possibility? Or is that kind of that off limits right now? componenttext: This is Ralph. Well, we've got several things we're doing. Obviously we're with Apco and the adre loman concession [ph]  We continue to do well in our major concessions down there which is the Entre Roman [ph], the Bahamas Pallum [ph], Agua de Marga [ph]. We also are in the process of testing some re-completion in that area of the Bottom Northending Shale [ph] and we're just in the early stage of that. It's an old vertical well so we're testing and we have a substantial amount of acreage that is exposed to the Bakken Morte [ph] and we've accord to continue to test that acreage as we move through. Early on, we'll just be testing some vertical wells in the Gulf and then we'll do some horizontal drilling also as we find the areas that we like.

componenttextpreview: Holly, basically it's a combination of radion laser and also some radion infrastructure in the Westmoreland Center County. And those, the Westmoreland Center County are in the process -- they will be fixed here, most of that, in the very near future. So a
componenttext: Holly, basically it's a combination of radion laser and also some radion infrastructure in the Westmoreland Center County. And those, the Westmoreland Center County are in the process -- they will be fixed here, most of that, in the very near future. So about half of our 30 subwells that we're waiting on completion are in that area so we look forward to those coming on. In fact, that 2 wells come on. And probably Eushack area [ph] just over the weekend. So we do believe, as we said in the -- on our slides that production should ramp up rapidly as we alleviate the concerns of the transportation, particularly the laser pipeline comes on it. I think we put that we would have a total volumes -- and just Susquehanna by the end of the year 70 million a day, so we look for a rapid ramp up.  Our wells, our rigs right now are operating in the -- 1 in Susquehanna and the others are -- 1 in Columbia County and the Grasmere and Westmoreland Center and Clearfield Counties.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011

componenttext: Okay. Perfect. And then just maybe a bigger picture question for Alan. Do you guys have an internal forecast at this point of what you expect the ramping ethane supply say maybe between now and 2014?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: We don't have a specific number. We watched that and we watched that balance very closely but we do not have a specific volume forecast for that so to answer your question is no. I would tell you that we remain pretty confident and because I said earlier
componenttext:
We don't have a specific number. We watched that and we watched that balance very closely but we do not have a specific volume forecast for that so to answer your question is no. I would tell you that we remain pretty confident and because I said earlier in the creek that will go on in all of these facilities that are either heavy crackers, continue and convert to live, there's still a lot of efficiency being gained in that area and I think we'll see that for the next couple of years and again as I mentioned, projects like our own at Grasmere. And so I think we'll continue to see that and then I think those big projects in the 3 to 4-year timeframe, those big projects will start to kick in. Some of those projects that have been announced are very large scale projects and will take a long time. 
In between those 2 things, there's also going to be I think expansions to existing facilities that will be rather significant and I think the current margin environment and the confidence in crude to gas right now is going to continue to have people investing in that space as well. And so I think it's rare that we have on the ethane and ethylene side, ethylene cracking, it's rare that we see the 2 things build at the same time. But because the margins in this environment, the margins are so strong in both spaces, I think we'll continue to see the ethanes supplies build. I think we'll continue to see the ethane cracking capabilities build as well. Then may be a few rocky steps here and there but right now, the trajectory looks pretty good.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next, we'll go to Craig Shere with Tuohy Brothers.
componenttext: Next, we'll go to Craig Shere with Tuohy Brothers.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good quarter. A couple of quick questions of derisking from a commodity risk standpoint. Alan, you've been talking for some months about the possibility of finding long-term ethane offtakers with the petro chems, but in some of the more recent earnings ca
componenttext: Good quarter. A couple of quick questions of derisking from a commodity risk standpoint. Alan, you've been talking for some months about the possibility of finding long-term ethane offtakers with the petro chems, but in some of the more recent earnings calls, industry peers kind of commented something similar to what you just said that, that it's not overly tight, it's not overly loose, but the petro chem's key sufficient supply at this time with no immediate need for long-term bilateral contracting. Can you comment on this and whether you see a different line of thinking from the petro chems as some of them contemplate some of these larger greenfield construction projects of worldscale crackers.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: I certainly think the folks that we talk to, and of course, we have own vantage point via our own PetChem space their. But I certainly think that the investors in that space recognize that there's very high margins right now available to them and I think
componenttext: I certainly think the folks that we talk to, and of course, we have own vantage point via our own PetChem space their. But I certainly think that the investors in that space recognize that there's very high margins right now available to them and I think they are leery of seeing the demand get overheated in the space right now. And so if I can just tell you folks that we continue to talk to and continue to work towards some structured arrangements like that, are obviously very concerned about long-term supply and I think the effort that I think is the smart decision for the industry to look at is to look to the total pie between gas and crude and that comes back to gas polyethylene or other ethylene derivatives. And to figure out how they can assure themselves a portion of that margin that allows them to invest in infrastructure going forward that's got more stable earnings behind it, rather than a winner and a loser across that chain but figuring out how that margin can be shared in a way that allows both parties to invest going forward in a very adequate return that exists out there.  And I hope, I certainly think, that the current margin environment in both those sectors doesn't lead to arrogance that will cause people to forget the past. And certainly right, the folks we're talking to, anyway, and are interested in working with, I don't think that's the case.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: In terms of the timeline, I think last call or the one before, you may have mentioned that it certainly wouldn't be before second half of this year possibly into early next year that we see some long-term agreement if it came. Is that timeline still there
componenttext: In terms of the timeline, I think last call or the one before, you may have mentioned that it certainly wouldn't be before second half of this year possibly into early next year that we see some long-term agreement if it came. Is that timeline still there or is it maybe being pushed out a little bit?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: I would say we're up against those discussions and it's kind of hard to call the counterparty moves on those. I can tell you there's nothing imminent at this point in time and we would certainly have liked to work to be there but there's nothing at this p
componenttext: I would say we're up against those discussions and it's kind of hard to call the counterparty moves on those. I can tell you there's nothing imminent at this point in time and we would certainly have liked to work to be there but there's nothing at this point in time. But again, I think the motives are strong for the players and we'll continue to push in that direction. Obviously, one of the options we have is to do similar arrangements with our own ethylene cracking and look to margin sharing at the MB level and so those are the kind of things that keep us from being too soft in our negotiations as our ability to do it ourselves there at our Grasmere facility.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: You know, that's starting to be explored by folks. You're starting to see a lot of people that are exploiting their contacts in India and China and places like that where the domain continues to grow and so I would keep tuned to that space, that's a great
componenttext: You know, that's starting to be explored by folks. You're starting to see a lot of people that are exploiting their contacts in India and China and places like that where the domain continues to grow and so I would keep tuned to that space, that's a great question and I'll tell you that's where a lot of the air traffic is right now is between the India and China in the PetChem space and a little bit of South America as well with people wanting to make sure that they can shore up those markets and have some risk reduction in those forward-looking markets out there. So there is a lot going on but it's brand-new and most of those, a lot of that buyers on that end aren't used to doing these longer-term structured contracts so even though there's a desire and a need there, there really hasn't been a blueprint there in the past. So there's new ground being broken in that area but you're spot on with kind of where the thinking is going in that area.

componenttext: The business up there, as you can see by the number, is performing really well. I think at this point our cash demands aren't going to be totally funded by cash flow up there, but a very large portion of it is going to be on earnings. We also have some optional accounts that we use to fund international investments like Canada. And so for the most we think we're going to be able to handle that load with dollars and probably wouldn't be available do this anyway.

componenttext: I guess just lastly maybe a broader question to WPC and the coverage ratio, I just wonder if you can comment  [indiscernible] how you do that, evolving over time and I think maybe that excess cash at PZ because you set the dividend based on lower commodity assumption is you do a special dividend or how you could see to fund your stock and debt as at PNG as you've historically done.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Don Chappel. I would say that we just don't foresee a situation in which it's likely that PZ is going to build cash since we have such abundant growth opportunities. I think the excess earnings will just be re-invested, which will reduce our needs
componenttext: This is Don Chappel. I would say that we just don't foresee a situation in which it's likely that PZ is going to build cash since we have such abundant growth opportunities. I think the excess earnings will just be re-invested, which will reduce our needs to go to the capital markets to raise capital at PZ. So I would say with the high margin PZ becomes more self-funding, not to say that the plant Wallmocore [ph] outside financing but all that excess cash to the extent that it's in at a level -- it's based on margins that are leveled -- we don't think our prudent to build into distributions will just be reinvested so we don't see idle cash sitting at PZ at all.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then with respect to whatever your view is on normalized commodity margins, what kind of distribution ratio or coverage ratio relative you think it's appropriate to target at PZ over time?
componenttext: And then with respect to whatever your view is on normalized commodity margins, what kind of distribution ratio or coverage ratio relative you think it's appropriate to target at PZ over time?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'd say it's a function of business mix and we're continuing to slowly add more and more key business in the Midstream business not to say that we're not adding commodity exposures as well, but proportionately, we're adding -- focused on adding a bit more
componenttext: I'd say it's a function of business mix and we're continuing to slowly add more and more key business in the Midstream business not to say that we're not adding commodity exposures as well, but proportionately, we're adding -- focused on adding a bit more on the fee side than we are on the commodity side. So we would expect our Fee business to create as a percentage of the total, which will enable us to, over time, have a lower coverage margin then it's a function of how comfortable are we with margins. So I think it depends where we are in the range and in what moment in time but we'd certainly like to see that drift down. I think right now, we're kind of looking at a kind of 1.2x coverage under something that might have been more like the beginning of the year margins versus what we're seeing today.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Williams Companies First Quarter 2011 Earnings Release Conference. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Travis Campbell, Head of Investor Relations. Please go
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Williams Companies First Quarter 2011 Earnings Release Conference. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Travis Campbell, Head of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everybody. Welcome to our First Quarter 2011 Earnings Call. As always, thanks for your interest in the company. As you no doubt know, we released our results yesterday after the market closed. Also yesterday, Alan, using a few sli
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, everybody. Welcome to our First Quarter 2011 Earnings Call. As always, thanks for your interest in the company. As you no doubt know, we released our results yesterday after the market closed. Also yesterday, Alan, using a few slides, had some commentary about the results, our increased guidance and our growth opportunities. That audio commentaries and slides are available on the website, and because of that review yesterday, we'll not be reviewing the slides again this morning. So on our website, williams.com, you should be able to find a number of things that were posted yesterday afternoon. First, the earnings presentation with the audio commentary by Alan. Second, the data book that contains the usual information we make available every quarter. Third, the press release of the first quarter results. Fourth, our analyst package. And finally, a pod cast of Alan's remarks yesterday. 
Also for your information, the first quarter 10-Q will be filed today. Because we reviewed these items yesterday, I expect the call today will be very brief and we'll get very quickly to your questions. In a minute, Alan Armstrong, our President and CEO, will make some general comments, after which we'll open the lines for questions. 
Be aware, as always, all of our business unit heads are here and available to respond to your questions after Alan's remarks. Here with me are Ralph Hill, who heads up the E&P Company; Rory Miller, who oversees the Midstream Company; and Randy Bernard, who heads up the gas pipeline. Also, Don Chappel, the CFO is here as well. 
As most of you are aware, last Friday we announced that our wholly owned subsidiary, WPX Energy, Inc., filed a registration statement related to the proposed IPO of its common stock. Because of security law restrictions, we will not be commenting at all on WPX Energy Inc. today. 
There are forward-looking statements on Slide 2 and 3 and disclaimer on oil and gas reserves on Slide 4 of yesterday's presentation. Those are also included in the data book. They're important and integral to the company and you should review those. 
Also, there are non-GAAP numbers included in these various presentations. Those have all been reconciled back to generally accepted accounting principles and their reconciliation schedules are also available. So with that, I'll turn it over to Alan.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. Good morning and thanks for joining us this morning. I'll just very briefly capture the highlights and key notes on what was put out as a recording yesterday and is in the slide material. First of all, we're very excited to tell you we're raising g
componenttext:
Great. Good morning and thanks for joining us this morning. I'll just very briefly capture the highlights and key notes on what was put out as a recording yesterday and is in the slide material. First of all, we're very excited to tell you we're raising guidance, and this is based on both higher crude price expectations. We are now at $95 midpoint for '11 and '12 crude. And of course, that's still well below the hoard market and current pricing for crude. And current NGL margins, of course, are being lifted on that. And in fact, current NGL margins are actually just beyond the high end of range of what we have posted right now. 
Also, we have greater confidence on timing and performance on a number of new projects that are going to add to the balance in 2011. So we are raising guidance for both '11 and '12, and you can see the details of that. We're now at a -- our midpoint for '11 is now $1.55 per share on an adjusted earnings basis. 
In the current quarter, we had mixed results to combine and produce a very solid quarter. Our gas gathering production volumes were negatively impacted by severe winter weather, primarily in the Rockies and in the Bakken, with the Bakken receiving near record snowfalls. And of course, low natural gas prices also grows low quarter-over-quarter results in E&P. 
However, our Midstream Canada and Olefins segment came through and posted a record quarter that helped to mitigate the weakness in the gas prices. And our Gas Pipe segment also came through with a strong quarter. 
As we look into the second quarter, we are very excited about how our volumes have rebounded and conditions are currently very good for tremendous earnings results for the balance of 2011. Looking to the balance of the year, we now expect our midpoint, as I stated earlier, EPS to be $1.55. And we're going to hit now just some of the key factors that we expect to drive this even better performance for the balance of the year. 
First of all, our operating volumes have really rebounded in all of our areas. We expect the balance of the year to be much better as the fruits of our labor in both the Marcellus and the Bakken begin to take hold both on the E&P side and in the Marcellus on the WPZ Midstream side. Also, we had some major maintenance to get through in the first quarter at our big Opal Plant, which is the largest single contributor to our NGL equity volumes. 
Secondly, new projects that we are expecting. First of all, Perdido Norte project really will be a powerful contributor to earnings in the last half of the year and not so really dependent on permitting out there as much as some continued topside work that Shell is doing on their big platform that feeds both our oil gathering, our gas gathering and our Markham processing plant that -- and of all those facilities serving the Western Deepwater Gulf of Mexico. So we're really looking forward to seeing those volumes start to ramp up and we have confidence in that happening for the balance of the year. 
Also,our Transco Pipeline just recently placed into service 2 new projects that will combine to generate over $30 million in additional profits for the balance of the year. And then finally the Marcellus, which is really infrastructure constrained on many fronts right now, will benefit from a lot of work that E&P did in getting a lot of small gathering systems in the field to serve new production in those areas as well as the laser pipeline, which -- and our very own Springville lateral, which we expect to begin in the third quarter. So a lot of things going on in the Marcellus, on the infrastructure front, some of which will directly impact our production and, of course, others that will drive earnings at the WPZ level. 
Third, on margins. We anticipate continued strong unit NGL margins and olefins margins. Our current forecast in margins for NGLs are really below what we are currently experiencing, and if you've noticed, we've really seen a nice shift up in ethane and as well as the heavier products continue to provide really record level margins. 
However, we also know that things can change pretty fast in this arena, so we are only raising our oil prices assumption to $95 and, we are holding back on our NGL crude ratio assumptions below what we're currently experiencing. 
On the olefins margin side, we continue to expect robust margins on this on the back of high crude oil because the rest of the world is really dependent on olefin products that are produced from crude oil, of course, and we continue to see growing demand for olefin derivative products outside the U.S. So we're really -- in the past, the U.S. petchem market was fairly dependent on the U.S. economy, and it's really moved offshore right now in terms of what we're depending on. 
We, of course, cannot say much at all about the spin off of our E&P segment, to be known as WPX Energy. I can tell you that the recent S-1 filing is spot on with what we told you to expect at the last earnings call. I can also speak to the positive impact that we expect to see at WMB. WMB is going to be one of the top interviewed infrastructure companies in the nation, and it is going to be better-positioned than any that I'm aware of in delivering reliable growing dividends. 
It will be investment grade and it will have the power of the increasing incentive distribution rights of the Williams Partners GP, and this is going to allow for continued growth and free cash flows and providing -- those will be available for dividends without dilution or financing expenses at the WMB level. 
So the clear and transparent growth at WPZ should provide confidence regarding our continued ability to grow distributions at the PZ level, and we have already declared a 60% increase for the WMB June dividend, and are targeting a 10% to 15% increase in dividend for the June 2012 WMB dividend. And, of course, these targets were set before the latest increase in guidance at both PZ and MB. 
So overall, we're very excited about the amount of value we expect to generate in the foreseeable future for our WMB shareholders, and we really are sitting at the right place, at the right time, with the right assets, the right experience and a great financial position to rapidly expand our business' earnings power. And with that, we'll turn this over for questions.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Carl Kirst with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Carl Kirst with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Nice results and certainly appreciate the streamlined version here. Alan, maybe if I can start just on the olefin margins, and certainly we've seen a good deal of new announcements to Dow, CP [Chevron Phillps] Chem, Formosa, everyone looking to ramp ethyl
componenttext: Nice results and certainly appreciate the streamlined version here. Alan, maybe if I can start just on the olefin margins, and certainly we've seen a good deal of new announcements to Dow, CP [Chevron Phillps] Chem, Formosa, everyone looking to ramp ethylene production in the Gulf Coast. And I'm trying to figure out with respect to Geismar and you guys trying to get a larger market share. Is that something where their interests should help where there's more opportunity maybe to find someone with an offtake, or are you finding more sort of direct competition as overall ethylene expansion perhaps, ramps?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Carl, for some reason we're having a really difficult time hearing you, but let me paraphrase what I thought I heard you ask and then hopefully, you can line me out if I didn't hear that right,but for some reason our audio on this end is breaking up. I th
componenttext:
Carl, for some reason we're having a really difficult time hearing you, but let me paraphrase what I thought I heard you ask and then hopefully, you can line me out if I didn't hear that right,but for some reason our audio on this end is breaking up. I think the question was around the -- what we expect in terms of the increase for demand in the petchem space and recognizing the new announcements from Dow and Chevron, Philips and some of the new announced Formosa, some of the new announcements on the pet chem side.  We are -- and I think then another question around what we would do at Geismar. First of all, on the ethane side, I think that we're pleased to see the big petchems continuing to see the same opportunity we see in terms of being able to export ethylene derivative products and having a very low-cost feedstock here in the U.S. to continue to provide that. And so I think it's really going to be a matter of timing in terms of when those facilities come up versus when the ethane shows up. But I will tell you that it is going to take a lot of the ethane projects and ethane supplies aren't going to show up tomorrow either. There's a lot of infrastructure required to get that ethane in place as well. So I think it's going to be a matter of how those things show up. 
But on balance, it looks pretty good from our vantage point in terms of the demand picking up with the available supply. And I would tell you that there's also going to be a lot of interim small projects. We announced our own small project there that we had at Geismar. I think we spent $18 million and got a small, I think a 3,000 to 5,000-barrel a day increase in ethane demand there. And there's going to be a lot of those kind of projects that continue to come out and what used to be referred to as refinery tree. We're going to see in the petchem space as well because the margins are absolutely there, and so I think those short-term kind of increases that people can squeeze out of their facilities, they're going to be doing. So I think -- hopefully that answered your question. I apologize, we couldn't quite hear it on this end.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Mainly, I was trying to figure out if the increase from the big pet chem guys would be an opportunity for Geismar, i.e, they would be an offtake of Geismar or if its direct competition to Geismar.
componenttext: Mainly, I was trying to figure out if the increase from the big pet chem guys would be an opportunity for Geismar, i.e, they would be an offtake of Geismar or if its direct competition to Geismar.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Those plans really are, at least what's been announced for the most part, is direct competition with Geismar, in terms of producing ethylene. But I would tell you that beyond the ethylene, obviously, is derivatives like polyethylene and ethylene oxide, et
componenttext: Those plans really are, at least what's been announced for the most part, is direct competition with Geismar, in terms of producing ethylene. But I would tell you that beyond the ethylene, obviously, is derivatives like polyethylene and ethylene oxide, ethylene glycol, and those derivatives are a lot less capital intensive. The facilities required for that are a lot less capital-intensive, and we're pretty well-positioned there at Geismar. There's a lot of growing derivative demand there at Geismar, and we're very well-positioned to be able to deliver against that. And we certainly have a lot of conversations going with folks that are wanting to expand the offtake there.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great, and then one other question if I could, just with respect to natural gas liquids production. I know there was a mention of a keep-whole contract that shifted a percent of proceeds, so I could understand why your equity production may have been down
componenttext: Great, and then one other question if I could, just with respect to natural gas liquids production. I know there was a mention of a keep-whole contract that shifted a percent of proceeds, so I could understand why your equity production may have been down slightly, but from sort of the gross NGL has produced, I was surprised to see that sequentially off from fourth quarter and didn't know if you could maybe comment as to where you saw that going for the rest of the year.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'm going to have Rory Miller take that one, Carl.
componenttext: I'm going to have Rory Miller take that one, Carl.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Carl, that's true, we are down first quarter. Other than the Exxon contract -- excuse me, some of the contracting issues that we had out there, that's a big part of the step down in production. But the other items, I would say, were our severe winter weat
componenttext: Carl, that's true, we are down first quarter. Other than the Exxon contract -- excuse me, some of the contracting issues that we had out there, that's a big part of the step down in production. But the other items, I would say, were our severe winter weather. We were down significantly at Opal in our volumes, Echo Springs and in Four Corners. So that had a pretty big impact on our total production and of course, our equity and NGL balance as well. We also had some major maintenance that was underway at Opal, and that's has been finished. And so we expect to see volumes in the second quarter back on the growth trajectory that we had planned and we forecast.

componenttext: First question is just on some of your Canadian spending. You talked about additional upgrade or processing, potentially adding a lot more project spending there. You've identified some spending. But I'm just wondering if you would expect to see the same returns on that or what the variability might be on the returns if you were to add on some of that greater processing?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: The opportunity is there and/or returns there probably will remain the same. I will tell you that I would kind of put them into maybe 4 different baskets of opportunities up there. And if you'll look at our slides, I think it's Slide 18 in our package, yo
componenttext: The opportunity is there and/or returns there probably will remain the same. I will tell you that I would kind of put them into maybe 4 different baskets of opportunities up there. And if you'll look at our slides, I think it's Slide 18 in our package, you'll see there we've got some of the segment profit, first year segment profits of those projects versus the capital shown there. And you'll see, for instance, the first category I would put as an optimization project, like our BB splitter, and you'll see there that's about a 3x cash flow kind of project. We invested $52 million, and our range is $15 million to $20 million in segment profits for the first year there.  And so those kind of projects will be very high returns like that. The Boreal pipeline you'll see is quite a bit lower return, and part of that is just because we were building for capacity for the future, and all you see there is just the first-year volumes before these additional projects come on. But I would expect those kind of projects to be in the low teens kind of returns for those pipeline kind of projects. And then the upgrader projects, where we actually are going in and building new upgraders, will be a matter of negotiation but are driven by a very high propylene margins. So there's quite a bit of opportunity there for us to capture, and it really boils down to how much we share with the upgrader. And we're in very good competitive position there in that we've got the pipeline now and the fractionator there at Redwater. But those would be probably in the high teens kind of returns.  And then the ethane recovery project that we did with Nova, not going to comment on that in terms of where that return is, but you can see what we expect for our first-year profit on that versus the capital investment on that. And you'll see that's about a little  over a 5 multiple in terms of what we're getting from that project. So I think that gives you a pretty good range of our expectations in that area, and we're certainly anxious to get more of that business up there.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then my other question was just -- if you look the dividend at WMB, and I appreciate the language that you expect strong increases beyond 2012. You raised the guidance at WPZ. Olefins and Canada are all doing well, so there's a lot of cash that's goin
componenttext: And then my other question was just -- if you look the dividend at WMB, and I appreciate the language that you expect strong increases beyond 2012. You raised the guidance at WPZ. Olefins and Canada are all doing well, so there's a lot of cash that's going to be coming out of WMB. I'm just wondering if you can comment on where you might see the growth in the dividend, whether it's even higher even in 2012 or as we go past 2012.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ted, this is Don Chappel. I'll take a stab at it first here, again. A lot of the upgrade in our guidance is related to very strong commodity price, and we certainly don't count on that when we set WPC distribution and count on that for our Williams' divid
componenttext: Ted, this is Don Chappel. I'll take a stab at it first here, again. A lot of the upgrade in our guidance is related to very strong commodity price, and we certainly don't count on that when we set WPC distribution and count on that for our Williams' dividends. So we really look at a much lower price margin environment as we think about WPC distributions and the Williams' dividend. So that would really guide our thinking, but even at that level, I think the 10% to 15% that we provided for guidance in '12 and strong growth beyond is still, we believe, is a conservative view of what we can accomplish. So we'll continue to look at it. We certainly appreciate that our stock price will, in large part, be driven by our ability to pay an increase of dividend, and we'll remain very focused on that. So I'd say, stay tuned beyond that.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: So I guess -- and it's probably early to talk about this. If you did have, let's say, excess returns on margins for, let's say the next couple, 3 years, would you then flip over to a buyback, or what would you do with the excess cash?
componenttext: So I guess -- and it's probably early to talk about this. If you did have, let's say, excess returns on margins for, let's say the next couple, 3 years, would you then flip over to a buyback, or what would you do with the excess cash?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ted, I think stock buyback would certainly be in the cards. I think, again, we're blessed with a lot of very attractive investment opportunities, so I think it'll be continuously weighing the potential reinvestment opportunities versus stock buyback. And
componenttext: Ted, I think stock buyback would certainly be in the cards. I think, again, we're blessed with a lot of very attractive investment opportunities, so I think it'll be continuously weighing the potential reinvestment opportunities versus stock buyback. And again, if it was a more sustainable cash flow stream, and then dividend would be the likely outcome.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
