headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: We're still staying in what we gave as the guidance at that time, which is a $7.5 million to $8.5 million range. But what we're seeing is now that we've taken over operations on the drilling side and we're still in the process of taking over operations on
componenttext: We're still staying in what we gave as the guidance at that time, which is a $7.5 million to $8.5 million range. But what we're seeing is now that we've taken over operations on the drilling side and we're still in the process of taking over operations on the completion in just the normal field operations, our first few wells that we have drilled are down into the lower 30-day range. Previous owner was more in the 40- to 50-day range. So we expect to be in that $7.5 million to $8.5 million as we put on our guidance. We're pleased with what we have, as Alan mentioned, early on in this winter, there's been some, obviously, a pretty severe winters and completion delays. But on the drilling side, we're very pleased at this time. And hope to have our completions caught up at some point this year.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to jump back to the distributions and I was wondering if there's any tax shield that we should be thinking about as you receive these reasons from WPZ. Just trying to understand the dynamics there a little better.
componenttext: I just wanted to jump back to the distributions and I was wondering if there's any tax shield that we should be thinking about as you receive these reasons from WPZ. Just trying to understand the dynamics there a little better.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Jonathan, Williams pays tax on WPZ's earnings, our proportionate share of WPZ earnings regardless of the distribution. So from a tax standpoint, we've filed a consolidated tax return and really kind of looks through the structure. So that really didn't ch
componenttext: Jonathan, Williams pays tax on WPZ's earnings, our proportionate share of WPZ earnings regardless of the distribution. So from a tax standpoint, we've filed a consolidated tax return and really kind of looks through the structure. So that really didn't change Williams' tax position relative to WPZ business, earnings didn't change. So I think we've said that you can probably look at the distribution, the ballpark, the taxes and apply something like a 30% rate on the distribution and get into the right zip code in terms of what the effective tax rate is on those earnings.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011

componenttext: And then just wanted to follow up on the MLP question. I know you answered about the Canadian assets not fitting into the MLP structure today. But I was just wondering, what about Grasmere, with that -- I know it could fit. But just wondering if you think that at some point, you might look to put that at WPZ?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: As I'm sure you're aware, that income is not qualified income from an MLP standpoint. However, given the size of WPZ and the scale that it's growing to, it doesn't mean that we could not at some point. But at this point, again, we've got enough growth pot
componenttext: As I'm sure you're aware, that income is not qualified income from an MLP standpoint. However, given the size of WPZ and the scale that it's growing to, it doesn't mean that we could not at some point. But at this point, again, we've got enough growth potential out there, we don't see a need to put that in at this time and bring that risk to bear for some [ph] tax standpoint.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just lastly, I know you have plenty of capacity to increase the dividend here. Just wondering how you maybe weigh that against the opportunity to do some share repurchases and how we should be thinking about that going forward.
componenttext: Just lastly, I know you have plenty of capacity to increase the dividend here. Just wondering how you maybe weigh that against the opportunity to do some share repurchases and how we should be thinking about that going forward.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: I would say that we think the dividend is very highly valued. Obviously, we think our stock is something that's also attractive. So we'll continue to look at the options there. I would say that right now, our bias is toward dividend. We think the market r
componenttext: I would say that we think the dividend is very highly valued. Obviously, we think our stock is something that's also attractive. So we'll continue to look at the options there. I would say that right now, our bias is toward dividend. We think the market really appreciates the dividend growth being kind of a long-term cash flow stream. But we'll continue to look at all the options.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just finally, for Ralph, I noticed the mention of the Niobrara is under review. Just wondering if maybe you could give us a little bit of color around that. And what your intentions are there? And maybe this, I assume, is the gas Niobrara?
componenttext: Just finally, for Ralph, I noticed the mention of the Niobrara is under review. Just wondering if maybe you could give us a little bit of color around that. And what your intentions are there? And maybe this, I assume, is the gas Niobrara?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, basically, what we're doing at this point is the gas Niobrara and that's in the Piceance Basin. We have some opportunities that we've mentioned previously that we're looking just in our normal acreage that we have to test some of the Niobrara in the
componenttext: Yes, basically, what we're doing at this point is the gas Niobrara and that's in the Piceance Basin. We have some opportunities that we've mentioned previously that we're looking just in our normal acreage that we have to test some of the Niobrara in the Piceance.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll move next to Craig Shere of Tuohy Brothers Investment Research.
componenttext: We'll move next to Craig Shere of Tuohy Brothers Investment Research.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Alan, you commented during the call already and also, I believe, back in November during some of your investor meetings that you'd certainly like to grow the U.S. olefins business, particularly to the degree it could serve as an off taker and reduce some
componenttext: Alan, you commented during the call already and also, I believe, back in November during some of your investor meetings that you'd certainly like to grow the U.S. olefins business, particularly to the degree it could serve as an off taker and reduce some of the risk for ethane price volatility from PZ. But you kind of mentioned today that you don't necessarily see a lot of demand there, even though plastics pricing is going up worldwide and there continues to be the ethane advantage versus alternative feedstock. Can you comment on that and the ability to drive down that coverage ratio that Don referred to at 1.2x?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Craig, thank you for the question actually because it gives me an opportunity to clarify that. When I spoke to demand, I wasn't speaking to really lack of demand on the pet chem side because as you know, ethylene derivative products like polyethylene are
componenttext: Craig, thank you for the question actually because it gives me an opportunity to clarify that. When I spoke to demand, I wasn't speaking to really lack of demand on the pet chem side because as you know, ethylene derivative products like polyethylene are very advantaged here in the U.S. relative to the rest of the world that primarily uses naphtha to produce that product. And so as we have continued below natural gas prices here, we continue to have a lot of opportunity in that regard. And we are very excited about that space. I would just say that we are also seeing a lot of interest by the pet chem space in moving upstream as well. And so there may be a way to reduce risk to our portfolio and lead people that are more in the business of ethylene-derivative business. And the exports of those products doing their expertise. And us doing the upstream in perhaps in a way that partners with those parties and reduces our risk. So that's why the capital isn't real large in that space right now as there's perhaps some partnering opportunities that give us visibility all the way through the polyethylene, for instance, but doesn't require us to put up a tremendous amount of capital in that space.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: And do you see the de-risking at PZ coming from long-term contracts that are less variable based, more fixed? Or simply linked more to a percentage of oil that can be hedged?
componenttext: And do you see the de-risking at PZ coming from long-term contracts that are less variable based, more fixed? Or simply linked more to a percentage of oil that can be hedged?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Either one and both of those avenues are being pursued. So I would say probably, more likely, for longer-term deals, it would be something tied to crude oil.
componenttext: Either one and both of those avenues are being pursued. So I would say probably, more likely, for longer-term deals, it would be something tied to crude oil.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ralph, two quick questions. I don't know if you'll answer the second one. But on the first one, it looks like, if I understood your answer to Carl's question and I'm doing the math right on Slide 11 with the how much you'll be spending on the Bakken, it l
componenttext: Ralph, two quick questions. I don't know if you'll answer the second one. But on the first one, it looks like, if I understood your answer to Carl's question and I'm doing the math right on Slide 11 with the how much you'll be spending on the Bakken, it looks like your CapEx for gas has not come down much, even though the gas strip is somewhat meaningfully lower than what was assumed in the third quarter guidance, which I think was $5 at that time. And the production guidance in 2011 doesn't seem to show much decline on the gas expectation. So the first question is, can you comment about your thinking and plans in terms of gassy CapEx investment relative to changes in commodity prices? And the second question is, whether as part of the broader family or on your own, I just wonder how much credit the street gives you for the 69% ownership in Apco and what you can do to kind of get that story out there?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, on the first side, we are basically holding this rig count we talked about for the gas side in November, which is about 11 rigs in the Piceance and three in the Marcellus Shale growing this year to approximately six, probably at the end of the year
componenttext: Well, on the first side, we are basically holding this rig count we talked about for the gas side in November, which is about 11 rigs in the Piceance and three in the Marcellus Shale growing this year to approximately six, probably at the end of the year in the Marcellus. We did drop three rigs from the Barnett, we're down to one and we have changed that around somewhat. We still think in those areas we're drilling in, which is primarily the Piceance and the Marcellus on the gas side, we feel very good about our returns there. So we're comfortable with that. And going forward, obviously, as we get our hands more and more around the Bakken side of the world, to the extent we can build our inventory, permitting, get our staff out there, we will probably look to when the time is right to shift those resources from the gassy side to the oily side. So we have -- at November call, you might recall, we did drop about 10 rigs from what we had previously thought we would be doing on the gas side. So we've already taken a pretty big cut at that. As for Apco, we continue to have a number of successes in Apco that you've seen in the past, and we'll just be able to talk about that somewhat when we go through the process. But you've seen that we have some slides out there now that talk about the concessions we have and both in Argentina and some concessions in Colombia, and that's just something we'll be able to talk about when we get through this process.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll move on to Kevin Smith of Raymond James.
componenttext: We'll move on to Kevin Smith of Raymond James.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: In the past, I guess, you guys have talked about the communication flow being a consolidated company and having all these different aspects and how you're able to jointly develop projects and the synergies from that. I don't know if we're getting too sens
componenttext: In the past, I guess, you guys have talked about the communication flow being a consolidated company and having all these different aspects and how you're able to jointly develop projects and the synergies from that. I don't know if we're getting too sensitive, but how do you see communication flow past the breakup?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll take that. Now first of all, certainly has been particularly between Midstream and E&P. A lot of opportunities for Midstream to kind of be ahead, and as well for Midstream to help the E&P group get fair value for their liquids as well. And so o
componenttext: Well, I'll take that. Now first of all, certainly has been particularly between Midstream and E&P. A lot of opportunities for Midstream to kind of be ahead, and as well for Midstream to help the E&P group get fair value for their liquids as well. And so on both fronts, I think there's been benefit there. So I wouldn't sit and deny that. Certainly through the IPO process, and as long as it's a controlled subsidiary, there's no reason that we would lose that. But ultimately, in the spin, we will have to work hard to maintain the good relationships and that certainly our goal as a management team right now is to maintain the good relationship and continue to be able to enjoy that to the degree we can legally.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Are there any gathering contracts or anything that will have to be kind of split out or is all that stuff already separate?
componenttext: Are there any gathering contracts or anything that will have to be kind of split out or is all that stuff already separate?

componenttextpreview: Because we have WPZ holding most of our Domestic Midstream business, most of that is squared away pretty well. So not any major deals at all, it'll be a little bit to clean up here and there, but for the most part, it's taken care of because we already ha
componenttext: Because we have WPZ holding most of our Domestic Midstream business, most of that is squared away pretty well. So not any major deals at all, it'll be a little bit to clean up here and there, but for the most part, it's taken care of because we already had the separate WPZ entity.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Ralph. We probably will have, I would guess in our next last call, some more update on that. We closed the deal December 21, have just now, as I mentioned, taken over the drilling side, and we have our staff in place. We've been blessed in the new
componenttext: This is Ralph. We probably will have, I would guess in our next last call, some more update on that. We closed the deal December 21, have just now, as I mentioned, taken over the drilling side, and we have our staff in place. We've been blessed in the new Marcellus team and also in the new Bakken team that we've been able to pull from resources in the Piceance, the Powder and the Barnett and bring a lot of expertise to each of those teams. So we're in the game right now. And I would guess that we'll start giving some updates at the next call and everything we've seen so far is what we thought it would be. So we're very pleased with that. The only thing we have, as Alan mentioned, I mentioned, where we have a little bit of completion backlog as I think most of the industry does up there. But with our relationships with our vendors nationwide, we think we'll be able to overcome that delay.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011

componenttext: And we'll move next to the Holly Stewart of Howard Weil.

componenttextpreview: We always will look to high grade the business. As we're speaking right now, we do have our KOMA [ph] positions for sale, if you will. But going forward, Holly, as we look at anything, we'll always look to make sure our portfolio is bringing the returns w
componenttext: We always will look to high grade the business. As we're speaking right now, we do have our KOMA [ph] positions for sale, if you will. But going forward, Holly, as we look at anything, we'll always look to make sure our portfolio is bringing the returns we want, and we'll just handle that as we move forward in the process. But we always want to make sure our portfolio is contributing.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011

componenttext: And you've dropped -- I guess you just mentioned you've dropped two rigs up in the Barnett. So is that just related to pricing right now, the economics? I know you guys have had some permitting issues. Just kind of trying to think about the value of the Newco [ph] E&P here going forward.

componenttext: It's really just a function of there've been some delays on the facility side and we have better places to -- because of that, we've had better places to pick our capital right now.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just as a last question on the separation. Can we assume or is it a good policy for us to assume that WPZ would enter into additional midstream and pipeline contracts with new E&P in the Marcellus and the Bakken prior to the actual spin?
componenttext: Just as a last question on the separation. Can we assume or is it a good policy for us to assume that WPZ would enter into additional midstream and pipeline contracts with new E&P in the Marcellus and the Bakken prior to the actual spin?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I really don't think we'd be able to comment on that. But I would just say that in a business as usual, where it makes sense for both parties and economically would continue to drive those kind of values for the corporation.
componenttext: Yes, I really don't think we'd be able to comment on that. But I would just say that in a business as usual, where it makes sense for both parties and economically would continue to drive those kind of values for the corporation.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Thank you very much. Appreciate the great attention this morning and the great questions. And we're certainly very excited about our future and hope you are as well.Again as I mentioned, we feel like in the current, we're certainly deliveri
componenttext:
Okay, great. Thank you very much. Appreciate the great attention this morning and the great questions. And we're certainly very excited about our future and hope you are as well.
Again as I mentioned, we feel like in the current, we're certainly delivering in our forecast, we've got great growth, identifiable growth. And in a longer-term future, we remain very excited about the prospects. So thank you again for joining us this morning.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: And again, that does conclude our conference. Thank you all for your participation.
componenttext: And again, that does conclude our conference. Thank you all for your participation.
